Lower bounds for predecessor searching in the cell probe model111 This paper is the journal version of the conference papers [SV01] and [Sen03].

Pranab Sen Department of Combinatorics and Optimization, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario N2L 3G1, Canada. Email: p2sen@iqc.ca. Work done while the author was a graduate student at TIFR, Mumbai, India visiting UC Berkeley and DIMACS under a Sarojini Damodaran International Fellowship grant, and a postdoctoral researcher at LRI, Orsay, France supported by the EU 5th framework program QAIP IST-1999-11234 and by CNRS/STIC 01N80/0502 and 01N80/0607 grants. â€ƒâ€ƒ SÂ .Venkatesh Algorithms and Complexity Group, Max-Planck Institut fÃ¼r Informatik, Stuhlsatzenhausweg 85, 66123 SaarbrÃ¼ken, Germany. Email: srini@mpi-sb.mpg.de. Work done while the author was a postdoctoral researcher at IAS, Princeton, USA supported by NSF grant CCR-9987845 and a joint IAS-DIMACS post doctoral fellowship.
Abstract

We consider a fundamental problem in data structures, static predecessor searching: Given a subset Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of size nğ‘›nitalic_n from the universe [m]delimited-[]ğ‘š[m][ italic_m ], store Sğ‘†Sitalic_S so that queries of the form â€œWhat is the predecessor of xğ‘¥xitalic_x in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S?â€ can be answered efficiently. We study this problem in the cell probe model introduced by YaoÂ [Yao81]. Recently, Beame and FichÂ [BF99] obtained optimal bounds on the number of probes needed by any deterministic query scheme if the associated storage scheme uses only nOâ¢(1)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1n^{O(1)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cells of word size (logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1)superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1(\log m)^{O(1)}( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bits.

We give a new lower bound proof for this problem that matches the bounds of Beame and Fich. Our lower bound proof has the following advantages: it works for randomised query schemes too, while Beame and Fichâ€™s proof works for deterministic query schemes only. In addition, it is simpler than Beame and Fichâ€™s proof. In fact, our lower bound for predecessor searching extends to the â€˜quantum address-onlyâ€™ query schemes that we define in this paper. In these query schemes, quantum parallelism is allowed only over the â€˜address linesâ€™ of the queries. These query schemes subsume classical randomised query schemes, and include many quantum query algorithms like Groverâ€™s algorithmÂ [Gro96].

We prove our lower bound using the round elimination approach of Miltersen, Nisan, Safra and WigdersonÂ [MNSW98]. Using tools from information theory, we prove a strong round elimination lemma for communication complexity that enables us to obtain a tight lower bound for the predecessor problem. Our strong round elimination lemma also extends to quantum communication complexity. We also use our round elimination lemma to obtain a rounds versus communication tradeoff for the â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem, improving on the tradeoff in [MNSW98]. We believe that our round elimination lemma is of independent interest and should have other applications.

1 Introduction

1.1 The problem and the model

A static data structure problem consists of a set of data Dğ·Ditalic_D, a set of queries Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, a set of answers Ağ´Aitalic_A, and a function f:DÃ—Qâ†’A:ğ‘“â†’ğ·ğ‘„ğ´f:D\times Q\rightarrow Aitalic_f : italic_D Ã— italic_Q â†’ italic_A. The aim is to store the data efficiently and succinctly, so that any query can be answered with only a few probes to the data structure. Static predecessor searching is a well studied problem in data structure design (see e.g.Â [vEBKZ77, vEB77, Wil85, And96, Ajt88, Mil94, MNSW98, BF99]). Data structures for answering predecessor queries can be used to construct data structures to answer other queries like rank (finding the number of elements in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S that are smaller than or equal to xğ‘¥xitalic_x) and nearest neighbour (finding an element in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S closest to xğ‘¥xitalic_x) efficiently. This motivates the need to design efficient data structures that support predecessor queries.

Let [m]delimited-[]ğ‘š[m][ italic_m ] denote the set of integers {0,â€¦,mâˆ’1}0â€¦ğ‘š1\{0,\ldots,m-1\}{ 0 , â€¦ , italic_m - 1 }.

Definition 1 (Static predecessor searching)

In the problem of (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor searching, we are given a subset Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of size nğ‘›nitalic_n from the universe [m]delimited-[]ğ‘š[m][ italic_m ]. Our goal is to store the set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S succinctly so that queries of the form â€œWhat is the predecessor of xğ‘¥xitalic_x in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S?â€ for xâˆˆ[m]ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘šx\in[m]italic_x âˆˆ [ italic_m ] can be answered with a few probes to the data structure. If xğ‘¥xitalic_x has no predecessor in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, that is, xğ‘¥xitalic_x is smaller than every element in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, then return a default value, say, âˆ’11-1- 1.

In this paper, we study the static predecessor searching problem in Yaoâ€™s cell probe modelÂ [Yao81]. The cell probe model is a natural and general model for proving upper and lower bound results in data structures.

Definition 2 (The cell probe model)

An (s,w,t)ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(s,w,t)( italic_s , italic_w , italic_t ) cell probe scheme for a static data structure problem f:DÃ—Qâ†’Anormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ·ğ‘„ğ´f:D\times Q\rightarrow Aitalic_f : italic_D Ã— italic_Q â†’ italic_A has two components: a storage scheme and a query scheme. The storage scheme stores the data dâˆˆDğ‘‘ğ·d\in Ditalic_d âˆˆ italic_D as a table Tâ¢[d]ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘‘T[d]italic_T [ italic_d ] of sğ‘ sitalic_s cells, each cell of word size wğ‘¤witalic_w bits. The storage scheme is classical deterministic. Given a query qâˆˆQğ‘ğ‘„q\in Qitalic_q âˆˆ italic_Q, the query scheme computes fâ¢(d,q)ğ‘“ğ‘‘ğ‘f(d,q)italic_f ( italic_d , italic_q ) by making at most tğ‘¡titalic_t probes to Tâ¢[d]ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘‘T[d]italic_T [ italic_d ], where each probe reads one cell at a time, and the probes can be adaptive. In a deterministic cell probe scheme the query scheme is classical deterministic, in a randomised cell probe scheme it is classical randomised, and in an address-only quantum cell probe scheme it is bounded error address-only quantum (defined in SectionÂ 2.1).

Since in the cell probe model we only charge a scheme for the number of probes made to memory cells and for the total number of cells of storage used, and all internal computation is for free, lower bounds proved in the cell probe model hold in all reasonable data structure models (e.g. the unit cost RAM with the same word size) and give us insight into the intrinsic difficulty of the problem.

The goal is to design cell probe schemes for (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor searching using small space i.e. s=nOâ¢(1)ğ‘ superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1s=n^{O(1)}italic_s = italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and w=Oâ¢(logâ¡m)ğ‘¤ğ‘‚ğ‘šw=O(\log m)italic_w = italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ), and at the same time making a small number of probes tğ‘¡titalic_t in the worst case.

1.2 Previous work

We start by describing the sequence of results that lead to the currently best known upper bounds for the (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor problem. For a long time, the best upper bound known for the predecessor problem was due to the data structures of van Emde Boas et al.Â [vEBKZ77, vEB77], and the data structures of Fredman and WillardÂ [FW93]. In their papers, van Emde Boas et al.Â [vEBKZ77, vEB77] gave a (Î©â¢(m),Oâ¢(logâ¡m),Oâ¢(logâ¡logâ¡m))Î©ğ‘šğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‚ğ‘š(\Omega(m),O(\log m),O(\log\log m))( roman_Î© ( italic_m ) , italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ) , italic_O ( roman_log roman_log italic_m ) ) deterministic cell probe solution for predecessor. The main drawback of their solution is that the number of cells used is very large. Later, WillardÂ [Wil85] reduced the number of cells used to Oâ¢(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ). Building on the work of van Emde Boas et al. and Willard, Fredman and WillardÂ [FW93], and AnderssonÂ [And96] designed (Oâ¢(n),Oâ¢(logâ¡m),Oâ¢(logâ¡n))ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‚ğ‘›(O(n),O(\log m),O(\sqrt{\log n}))( italic_O ( italic_n ) , italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ) , italic_O ( square-root start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) ) deterministic cell probe schemes for predecessor. Recently, Beame and FichÂ [BF99] improved on these upper bounds and showed a (Oâ¢(n2â¢logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n),Oâ¢(logâ¡m),t)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘¡\left(O\left(\frac{n^{2}\log n}{\log\log n}\right),O(\log m),t\right)( italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) , italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ) , italic_t ), where t=minâ¡{Oâ¢(logâ¡logâ¡mlogâ¡logâ¡logâ¡m),Oâ¢(logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)}ğ‘¡ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘šğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›t=\min\left\{O\left(\frac{\log\log m}{\log\log\log m}\right),O\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log n}{\log\log n}}\,\right)\right\}italic_t = roman_min { italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG ) , italic_O ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG end_ARG ) }, deterministic cell probe scheme for predecessor.

The first lower bound for the (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor problem was proved by AjtaiÂ [Ajt88], who showed that no (nOâ¢(1),Oâ¢(logâ¡m),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},O(\log m),t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ) , italic_t ) deterministic cell probe scheme for predecessor can have constant number of probes tğ‘¡titalic_t. MiltersenÂ [Mil94] observed that there is a close connection between the cell probe complexity of a data structure problem and the communication complexity of a related communication game, and used this to improve Ajtaiâ€™s lower bound to Î©â¢(logâ¡logâ¡m)Î©ğ‘š\Omega(\sqrt{\log\log m}\,)roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG ) probes. Recently, building on Ajtaiâ€™s and Miltersenâ€™s work, Beame and FichÂ [BF99] showed that their data structure described above is indeed optimal in the following sense: any (nOâ¢(1),2(logâ¡m)1âˆ’Î©â¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscript2superscriptğ‘š1Î©1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},2^{(\log m)^{1-\Omega(1)}},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - roman_Î© ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) deterministic cell probe scheme for predecessor must satisfy t=Î©â¢(logâ¡logâ¡mlogâ¡logâ¡logâ¡m)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘šğ‘št=\Omega\left(\frac{\log\log m}{\log\log\log m}\right)italic_t = roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG ) as a function of mğ‘šmitalic_m, and any (nOâ¢(1),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},(\log m)^{O(1)},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) deterministic cell probe scheme for predecessor must satisfy t=Î©â¢(logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘›ğ‘›t=\Omega\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log n}{\log\log n}}\,\right)italic_t = roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG end_ARG ) as a function of nğ‘›nitalic_n. Similar lower bounds were proved by XiaoÂ [Xia92]. We would like to stress here that all the above lower bound proofs are complicated with many technical details. Also, they hold for deterministic cell probe schemes only.

The result of Beame and Fich gives rise to the following two questions: does their lower bound hold for randomised query schemes as well? It has been observed recently that randomisation enormously helps in the case of membership queriesÂ [BMRV00] and approximate nearest neighbour queriesÂ [Liu03, KOR98, IM98, CR03], and one might believe that it could help answer predecessor queries quickly as well. Secondly, is it possible to give a simple proof of the lower bound result of Beame and Fich?

A partial answer to both of the above questions was given by Miltersen, Nisan, Safra and WigdersonÂ [MNSW98]. In their paper, they proved a general round elimination lemma for communication complexity. Using the connection between cell probe complexity of data structures and communication complexity, and their round elimination lemma, they showed the following lower bound for the predecessor problem: any (nOâ¢(1),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},(\log m)^{O(1)},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) randomised cell probe scheme for (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor must satisfy t=Î©â¢(logâ¡logâ¡m)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘št=\Omega(\sqrt{\log\log m}\,)italic_t = roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG ) as a function of mğ‘šmitalic_m, and t=Î©â¢((logâ¡n)1/3)ğ‘¡Î©superscriptğ‘›13t=\Omega((\log n)^{1/3})italic_t = roman_Î© ( ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) as a function of nğ‘›nitalic_n. Though the lower bound proved by [MNSW98] is weaker than that of [BF99], their approach had two advantages: their lower bound holds for randomised query schemes too, and the proof is much simpler. In their paper, Miltersen et al. ask if their round elimination based approach can be strengthened to obtain the lower bound of Beame and Fich.

1.3 Our Results

We answer the question posed by Miltersen, Nisan, Safra and Wigderson. Our main result in this paper shows that the lower bound of Beame and Fich holds for address-only quantum cell probe schemes (and hence, for randomised cell probe schemes) as well.

1.3.1 The Predecessor Problem

Result 1

Suppose there is a (nOâ¢(1),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},(\log m)^{O(1)},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) randomised cell probe scheme for the (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor problem with error probability less than 1/3131/31 / 3. Then,

  1. (a)

    t=Î©â¢(logâ¡logâ¡mlogâ¡logâ¡logâ¡m)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘šğ‘št=\Omega\left(\frac{\log\log m}{\log\log\log m}\right)italic_t = roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG ) as a function of mğ‘šmitalic_m;

  2. (b)

    t=Î©â¢(logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘›ğ‘›t=\Omega\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log n}{\log\log n}}\,\right)italic_t = roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG end_ARG ) as a function of nğ‘›nitalic_n.

The same lower bound also holds for address-only quantum cell probe schemes for static predecessor searching.

We prove our lower bound for predecessor searching by combining the approach in [MNSW98] with a new round elimination lemma for communication complexity. Our round elimination lemma is a strengthening of the one proved in Â [MNSW98], and we believe it is of independent interest.

1.3.2 An improved round elimination lemma

In this paper, all communication protocols are two-party. The error probability of a randomised or quantum communication protocol is defined as the maximum error of the protocol for any input. For a general introduction to (classical) communication complexity, see the book by Kushilevitz and NisanÂ [KN97].

Let f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µ:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z be any communication problem. Let us denote by f(n),Asuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ´f^{(n),A}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a new communication game in which Alice is given x1,x2,â€¦,xnâˆˆğ’³subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ’³x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}\in{\cal X}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X, and Bob is given yâˆˆğ’´ğ‘¦ğ’´y\in{\cal Y}italic_y âˆˆ caligraphic_Y, iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] and also copies of x1,x2,â€¦,xiâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Their task is to compute fâ¢(xi,y)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¦f(x_{i},y)italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ). f(n),Bsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğµf^{(n),B}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is defined similarly. Intuitively, if Alice starts the communication and her first message is much smaller than nğ‘›nitalic_n bits, then she is unlikely to send much useful information about xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to Bob as she is unaware of iğ‘–iitalic_i. So it should be possible to eliminate the first message of Alice, giving rise to a protocol where Bob starts, with one less round of communication, and having similar message complexity and error probability. The round elimination lemma captures this intuition.

Definition 3

A [t;l1,l2,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ([t;l1,l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t;l_{1},l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) communication protocol is one where Alice (Bob) starts the communication, the iğ‘–iitalic_ith message is lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bits long, and the communication goes on for tğ‘¡titalic_t rounds.

Result 2

Suppose the communication game f(n),Asuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ´f^{(n),A}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a [t;l1,l2,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol with error less than Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. Then, fğ‘“fitalic_f has a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol with error less than Ïµ=Î”Î´+(1/2)â¢(2â¢l1â¢lnâ¡2/n)1/2superscriptnormal-Î”italic-Ïµğ›¿12superscript2subscriptğ‘™12ğ‘›12\epsilon\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\delta+(1/2)(2l_{1}\ln 2/n)^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Î´ + ( 1 / 2 ) ( 2 italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ln 2 / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A similar result holds for public coin quantum protocols (defined in SectionÂ 2.2) too.

The proof of this lemma uses tools from information theory. In particular, we use the average encoding theorem of Klauck, Nayak, Ta-Shma and ZuckermanÂ [KNTZ01]. Intuitively, this theorem says that if the mutual information between a random variable and its randomised encoding is small, then the probability distributions on code words for various values of the random variable are indeed close to the average probability distribution on code words.

1.3.3 Applications to other problems

We prove our lower bound result for predecessor by actually proving a lower bound for the rank parity problem. In the rank parity problem, we need to store a subset Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of the universe [m]delimited-[]ğ‘š[m][ italic_m ] so that given a query element xâˆˆ[m]ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘šx\in[m]italic_x âˆˆ [ italic_m ], we can output whether the number of elements in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S less than or equal to xğ‘¥xitalic_x is even or odd. Lower bounds for rank parity imply similar lower bounds for some other data structure problems like point separationÂ [BF99] and two-dimensional reporting range queryÂ [MNSW98]. For details of the reduction from rank parity to the above problems, see the respective papers cited above.

Independently, the round elimination lemma has applications to problems in communication complexity. For example, let us consider communication protocols for the â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in which Alice and Bob are given bit strings xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y respectively of length nğ‘›nitalic_n each, and the goal is to find out if x>yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x>yitalic_x > italic_y or not (treating x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,yitalic_x , italic_y as integers between 00 and 2nâˆ’1superscript2ğ‘›12^{n}-12 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1). Miltersen, Nisan, Safra and WigdersonÂ [MNSW98], and SmirnovÂ [Smi88] have studied rounds versus communication tradeoffs for ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Miltersen et al. show an Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢2âˆ’Oâ¢(t))Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscript2ğ‘‚ğ‘¡\Omega\left(n^{1/t}2^{-O(t)}\right)roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_O ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) lower bound for tğ‘¡titalic_t-round bounded error public coin randomised protocols for ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Using our stronger round elimination lemma, we improve Miltersen et al.â€™s result.

Result 3

The bounded error public coin randomised tğ‘¡titalic_t-round communication complexity of ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is lower bounded by Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢tâˆ’2)normal-Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡2\Omega(n^{1/t}t^{-2})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). For bounded error quantum protocols with input-independent prior entanglement for ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have a lower bound of Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢tâˆ’1)normal-Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡1\Omega(n^{1/t}t^{-1})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Remark:

The lower bound for quantum protocols is better because, by definition, a quantum protocol always sends messages whose length is independent of the input.

There exists a bounded error classical randomised protocol for Gâ¢Tnğºsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›GT_{n}italic_G italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using tğ‘¡titalic_t rounds of communication and having a complexity of Oâ¢(n1/tâ¢logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡ğ‘›O(n^{1/t}\log n)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n ). Hence, for a constant number of rounds, our lower bound matches the upper bound to within logarithmic factors. For one round quantum protocols, our result implies an Î©â¢(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n)roman_Î© ( italic_n ) lower bound for Gâ¢Tnğºsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›GT_{n}italic_G italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which is optimal to within constant factors), improving upon the previous Î©â¢(n/logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘›ğ‘›\Omega(n/\log n)roman_Î© ( italic_n / roman_log italic_n ) lower bound of KlauckÂ [Kla00]. No rounds versus communication tradeoff for this problem, for more than one round, was known earlier in the quantum setting. If the number of rounds is unbounded, then there is a private coin classical randomised protocol for Gâ¢Tnğºsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›GT_{n}italic_G italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) rounds of communication and having a complexity of Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )Â [Nis93]. An Î©â¢(logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(\log n)roman_Î© ( roman_log italic_n ) lower bound for the bounded error quantum communication complexity of Gâ¢Tnğºsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›GT_{n}italic_G italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (irrespective of the number of rounds) follows from Kremerâ€™s resultÂ [Kre95] that the bounded error quantum communication complexity of a function is lower bounded (up to constant factors) by the logarithm of the one round (classical) deterministic communication complexity.

1.4 Our techniques

The starting point of our work is the paper of Miltersen, Nisan, Safra and WigdersonÂ [MNSW98] showing lower bounds for randomised cell probe schemes for predecessor. The crux of Miltersen et al.â€™s lower bound is the following round elimination lemma for communication complexity.


Fact (Round elimination lemma, [MNSW98]) Let f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µnormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z be a function. Let Ïµ,Î´>0italic-Ïµğ›¿0\epsilon,\delta>0italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ > 0 be real numbers. Suppose that Î´â‰¤Ïµ2â¢(100â¢lnâ¡(8/Ïµ))âˆ’1ğ›¿superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscript1008italic-Ïµ1\delta\leq\epsilon^{2}(100\ln(8/\epsilon))^{-1}italic_Î´ â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 100 roman_ln ( 8 / italic_Ïµ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Suppose the communication game f(n),Asuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ´f^{(n),A}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol with error less than Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. Also suppose that nâ‰¥20â¢(l1â¢lnâ¡2+lnâ¡5)â¢Ïµâˆ’1ğ‘›20subscriptğ‘™125superscriptitalic-Ïµ1n\geq 20(l_{1}\ln 2+\ln 5)\epsilon^{-1}italic_n â‰¥ 20 ( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ln 2 + roman_ln 5 ) italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then there is a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol for fğ‘“fitalic_f with error less than Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ.


Note that in the round elimination lemma of [MNSW98], the dependence between Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ is quadratic. In their paper, Miltersen et al. ask if their round elimination based approach can be strengthened to obtain Beame and Fichâ€™sÂ [BF99] lower bound.

Our first observation is that if we can prove a stronger round elimination lemma in which Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ are related by a small additive term, and the additive term is upper bounded by (l1n)Î©â¢(1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘›Î©1(\frac{l_{1}}{n})^{\Omega(1)}( divide start_ARG italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then we can obtain the lower bound of Beame and Fich for randomised cell probe schemes solving the predecessor problem.

Our next observation is that Klauck, Nayak, Ta-Shma and ZuckermanÂ [KNTZ01] have studied rounds versus quantum communication tradeoffs for the â€˜tree pointer chasingâ€™ problem using tools from quantum information theory. In fact, their quantum lower bound for the â€˜tree pointer chasingâ€™ problem is better than its previously known classical lower boundÂ [MNSW98]! An important ingredient of their quantum lower bound was a quantum information-theoretic result called average encoding theorem. This result says informally that when messages carry very little information about the input, the average message is essentially as good as the individual messages. This result gives us a new way of attacking the round elimination problem. The information-theoretic round reduction arguments in [KNTZ01] are average-case (under the uniform distribution on the inputs) arguments, and do not immediately give a worst-case result like the round elimination lemma. The information-theoretic arguments have to be combined with Yaoâ€™s minimax lemmaÂ [Yao77] (also used in the proof of the round elimination lemma in [MNSW98]) to prove the strong round elimination lemma of this paper. The information-theoretic approach brings out more clearly the intuition behind round elimination, as opposed to the ad hoc combinatorial proof in [MNSW98]. We believe that this strong round elimination lemma is an important technical contribution of this paper.

1.5 Organisation of the paper

We start with some preliminaries in the next section. Assuming the average encoding theorem, we prove an intermediate result in SectionÂ 3 which allows us to reduce the number of rounds of a communication protocol if the first message does not convey much information about the senderâ€™s input. Proofs of the classical and quantum versions of the average encoding theorem can be found in the appendix for completeness. Using the intermediate result, we prove our strong round elimination lemma in SectionÂ 4. SectionsÂ 3 and 4 each have two subsections: the first one treats the classical version of the results and the second one treats the quantum version. Using the strong round elimination lemma, we prove the optimal lower bound for the predecessor problem in SectionÂ 5. The rounds versus communication tradeoff for the â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem is sketched in SectionÂ 6. We finally conclude mentioning some open problems in SectionÂ 7.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 The address-only quantum cell probe model

A quantum (s,w,t)ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(s,w,t)( italic_s , italic_w , italic_t ) cell probe scheme for a static data structure problem f:DÃ—Qâ†’A:ğ‘“â†’ğ·ğ‘„ğ´f:D\times Q\rightarrow Aitalic_f : italic_D Ã— italic_Q â†’ italic_A has two components: a classical deterministic storage scheme that stores the data dâˆˆDğ‘‘ğ·d\in Ditalic_d âˆˆ italic_D in a table Tâ¢[d]ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘‘T[d]italic_T [ italic_d ] using sğ‘ sitalic_s cells each containing wğ‘¤witalic_w bits, and a quantum query scheme that answers queries by â€˜quantumly probing a cell at a timeâ€™ tğ‘¡titalic_t times. Formally speaking, the table Tâ¢[d]ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘‘T[d]italic_T [ italic_d ] is made available to the query algorithm in the form of an oracle unitary transform Odsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘O_{d}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To define Odsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘O_{d}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT formally, we represent the basis states of the query algorithm as |j,b,zâŸ©ketğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘§|j,b,z\rangle| italic_j , italic_b , italic_z âŸ©, where jâˆˆ[sâˆ’1]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘ 1j\in[s-1]italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_s - 1 ] is a binary string of length logâ¡sğ‘ \log sroman_log italic_s, bğ‘bitalic_b is a binary string of length wğ‘¤witalic_w, and zğ‘§zitalic_z is a binary string of some fixed length. Here, jğ‘—jitalic_j denotes the address of a cell in the table Tâ¢[d]ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘‘T[d]italic_T [ italic_d ], bğ‘bitalic_b denotes the qubits which will hold the contents of a cell and zğ‘§zitalic_z stands for the rest of the qubits (â€˜work qubitsâ€™) in the query algorithm. Odsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘O_{d}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT maps |j,b,zâŸ©ketğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘§|j,b,z\rangle| italic_j , italic_b , italic_z âŸ© to |j,bâŠ•Tâ¢[d]j,zâŸ©ketğ‘—direct-sumğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘§|j,b\oplus T[d]_{j},z\rangle| italic_j , italic_b âŠ• italic_T [ italic_d ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âŸ©, where Tâ¢[d]jğ‘‡subscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘—T[d]_{j}italic_T [ italic_d ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a bit string of length wğ‘¤witalic_w and denotes the contents of the jğ‘—jitalic_jth cell in Tâ¢[d]ğ‘‡delimited-[]ğ‘‘T[d]italic_T [ italic_d ]. A quantum query scheme with tğ‘¡titalic_t probes is just a sequence of unitary transformations

U0â†’Odâ†’U1â†’Odâ†’â€¦â¢Utâˆ’1â†’Odâ†’Utâ†’subscriptğ‘ˆ0subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘â†’subscriptğ‘ˆ1â†’subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘â†’â€¦subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1â†’subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘â†’subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡U_{0}\rightarrow O_{d}\rightarrow U_{1}\rightarrow O_{d}\rightarrow\ldots U_{t-1}\rightarrow O_{d}\rightarrow U_{t}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ â€¦ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

where Ujsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘—U_{j}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are arbitrary unitary transformations that do not depend on dğ‘‘ditalic_d (Ujsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘—U_{j}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s represent the internal computations of the query algorithm). For a query qâˆˆQğ‘ğ‘„q\in Qitalic_q âˆˆ italic_Q, the computation starts in a computational basis state |qâŸ©â¢|0âŸ©ketğ‘ket0|q\rangle|0\rangle| italic_q âŸ© | 0 âŸ©, where we assume that the ancilla qubits are initially in the basis state |0âŸ©ket0|0\rangle| 0 âŸ©. Then we apply in succession, the operators U0,Od,U1,â€¦,Utâˆ’1,Od,Utsubscriptğ‘ˆ0subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ˆ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘¡U_{0},O_{d},U_{1},\ldots,U_{t-1},O_{d},U_{t}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and measure the final state. The answer consists of the values on some of the output wires of the circuit. We say that the scheme has worst case error probability less than Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ if the answer is equal to fâ¢(d,q)ğ‘“ğ‘‘ğ‘f(d,q)italic_f ( italic_d , italic_q ), for every (d,q)âˆˆDÃ—Qğ‘‘ğ‘ğ·ğ‘„(d,q)\in D\times Q( italic_d , italic_q ) âˆˆ italic_D Ã— italic_Q, with probability greater than 1âˆ’Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1-\epsilon1 - italic_Ïµ. The term â€˜bounded error quantum schemeâ€™ means that Ïµ=1/3italic-Ïµ13\epsilon=1/3italic_Ïµ = 1 / 3.

We now formally define the address-only quantum cell probe model. Here the storage scheme is classical deterministic as before, but the query scheme is restricted to be â€˜address-only quantumâ€™. This means that the state vector before a query to the oracle Odsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘O_{d}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is always a tensor product of a state vector on the address and work qubits (the (j,z)ğ‘—ğ‘§(j,z)( italic_j , italic_z ) part in (j,b,z)ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘§(j,b,z)( italic_j , italic_b , italic_z ) above), and a state vector on the data qubits (the bğ‘bitalic_b part in (j,b,z)ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘§(j,b,z)( italic_j , italic_b , italic_z ) above). The state vector on the data qubits before a query to the oracle Odsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘‘O_{d}italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of the query element qğ‘qitalic_q and the data dğ‘‘ditalic_d but can vary with the probe number. Intuitively, we are only making use of quantum parallelism over the address lines of a query. This mode of querying a table subsumes classical (deterministic or randomised) querying, and also many non-trivial quantum algorithms like Groverâ€™s algorithmÂ [Gro96], Farhi et al.â€™s algorithmÂ [FGGS99], HÃ¸yer et al.â€™s algorithmÂ [HNS02] etc. satisfy the â€˜address-onlyâ€™ condition. For classical (deterministic or randomised) querying, the state vector on the data qubits is |0âŸ©ket0|0\rangle| 0 âŸ©, independent of the probe number. For Groverâ€™s algorithm and Farhi et al.â€™s algorithm, the state vector on the data qubit is (|0âŸ©âˆ’|1âŸ©)/2ket0ket12(|0\rangle-|1\rangle)/\sqrt{2}( | 0 âŸ© - | 1 âŸ© ) / square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG, independent of the probe number. For HÃ¸yer et al.â€™s algorithm, the state vector on the data qubit is |0âŸ©ket0|0\rangle| 0 âŸ© for some probe numbers, and (|0âŸ©âˆ’|1âŸ©)/2ket0ket12(|0\rangle-|1\rangle)/\sqrt{2}( | 0 âŸ© - | 1 âŸ© ) / square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG for the other probe numbers.

2.2 Quantum communication protocols

In this paper, we adopt the â€˜interacting unitary quantum circuitsâ€™ definition of quantum communication protocols of YaoÂ [Yao93]. Thus, Alice and Bob send a certain number of fixed length messages to each other, and the number and length of these messages is independent of their inputs. If Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs are in computational basis states, the global state of all the qubits of Alice and Bob is pure at all times during the execution of the protocol. Measurements are not allowed during the execution of the protocol. At the end of the protocol, the last recipient of a message make a von Neumann measurement in the computational basis of certain qubits (the â€˜answer qubitsâ€™) in her possession in order to determine the answer of the protocol. The choice of â€˜answer qubitsâ€™ is independent of Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs.

We require that Alice and Bob make a secure copy of their inputs before beginning the quantum communication protocol. This is possible since the inputs to Alice and Bob are in computational basis states e.g. CNOT gates can be used for this purpose. Thus, without loss of generality, the input qubits of Alice and Bob are never sent as messages, their state remains unchanged throughout the protocol, and they are never measured i.e. some work qubits are measured to determine the result of the protocol. We call such quantum protocols secure and will assume henceforth that all our quantum protocols are secure.

We now define the concept of a safe quantum communication protocol, which will be used in the statement of the quantum round elimination lemma.

Definition 4 (Safe quantum protocol)

A [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ([t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) safe quantum communication protocol is a secure quantum protocol where Alice (Bob) starts the communication, the first message is l1+csubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘l_{1}+citalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c qubits long, the iğ‘–iitalic_ith message, for iâ‰¥2ğ‘–2i\geq 2italic_i â‰¥ 2, is lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT qubits long, and the communication goes on for tğ‘¡titalic_t rounds. We think of the first message as having two parts: the â€˜main partâ€™ which is l1subscriptğ‘™1l_{1}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT qubits long, and the â€˜safe overhead partâ€™ which is cğ‘citalic_c qubits long. The density matrix of the â€˜safe overheadâ€™ is independent of the inputs to Alice and Bob.

Remarks:

1. Â Â The safe overhead is nothing but a way to send input independent prior entanglement from Alice to Bob. The reason we use this notation is that we will later define safe public coin quantum protocols where there will be two kinds of input independent prior entanglement, the first being the one provided by the safe overhead and the second being the one proved by the public coin.
2. Â Â The reason for defining the concept of a safe overhead, intuitively speaking, is as follows. The communication games arising from data structure problems often have an asymmetry between the message lengths of Alice and Bob. This asymmetry is crucial to prove lower bounds on the number of rounds of communication. In the previous quantum round reduction arguments (e.g. those of Klauck et al.Â [KNTZ01]), the complexity of the first message in the protocol increases quickly as the number of rounds is reduced and the asymmetry gets lost. This leads to a problem where the first message soon gets big enough to potentially convey substantial information about the input of one player to the other, destroying any hope of proving strong lower bounds on the number of rounds. The concept of a safe protocol allows us to get around this problem. We show through a careful quantum information theoretic analysis of the round reduction process, that in a safe protocol, though the complexity of the first message increases a lot, this increase is confined to the safe overhead and so, the information content does not increase much. This is the key property which allows us to prove a round elimination lemma for safe quantum protocols.

In this paper we will deal with quantum protocols with public coins. Intuitively, a public coin quantum protocol is a probability distribution over finitely many (coinless) quantum protocols. We shall henceforth call the standard definition of a quantum protocol without prior entanglement as coinless. Our definition is similar to the classical scenario, where a randomised protocol with public coins is a probability distribution over finitely many deterministic protocols. We note however, that our definition of a public coin quantum protocol is not the same as that of a quantum protocol with prior entanglement, which has been studied previously (see e.g.Â [CvDNT98]). Our definition is weaker, in that it does not allow the unitary transformations of Alice and Bob to alter the â€˜public coinâ€™.

Definition 5 (Public coin quantum protocol)

In a quantum protocol with a public coin, there is, before the start of the protocol, a quantum state called a public coin, of the form âˆ‘cpcâ¢|câŸ©Aâ¢|câŸ©Bsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptketğ‘ğ´subscriptketğ‘ğµ\sum_{c}\sqrt{p_{c}}|c\rangle_{A}|c\rangle_{B}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | italic_c âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_c âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where the subscripts denote ownership of qubits by Alice and Bob, pcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{c}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are finitely many non-negative real numbers and âˆ‘cpc=1subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘1\sum_{c}p_{c}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Alice and Bob make (entangled) copies of their respective halves of the public coin using CNOT gates before commencing the protocol. The unitary transformations of Alice and Bob during the protocol do not touch the public coin. The public coin is never measured, nor is it ever sent as a message.

Hence, one can think of the public coin quantum protocol to be a probability distribution, with probability pcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{c}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, over finitely many coinless quantum protocols indexed by the coin basis states |câŸ©ketğ‘|c\rangle| italic_c âŸ©. A safe public coin quantum protocol is similarly defined as a probability distribution over finitely many safe coinless quantum protocols.

Remarks:

1.Â Â We need to define public coin quantum protocols in order to make use of the harder direction of Yaoâ€™s minimax lemmaÂ [Yao77]. The minimax lemma is the main tool which allows us to convert â€˜average caseâ€™ round reduction arguments to â€˜worst caseâ€™ arguments. We need â€˜worst caseâ€™ round reduction arguments in proving lower bounds for the rounds complexity of communication games arising from data structure problems. This is because many of these lower bound proofs use some notion of â€œself-reducibilityâ€, arising from the original data structure problem, which fails to hold in the â€˜average caseâ€™ but holds for the â€˜worst caseâ€™. The quantum round reduction arguments of Klauck et al.Â [KNTZ01] are â€˜average caseâ€™ arguments, and this is one of the reasons why they do not suffice to prove lower bounds for the rounds complexity of communication games arising from data structure problems.
2.Â Â  For [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe quantum protocols computing a function fğ‘“fitalic_f, Yaoâ€™s minimax lemma says that the infimum (worst-case) error of a public coin protocol is equal to the supremum over all input probability distributions of the infimum distributional error of a coinless protocol.

2.3 Predecessor searching and communication complexity

We first describe the connection between the address-only quantum cell probe complexity of a static data structure problem and the quantum communication complexity of an associated communication game. Let f:DÃ—Qâ†’A:ğ‘“â†’ğ·ğ‘„ğ´f:D\times Q\rightarrow Aitalic_f : italic_D Ã— italic_Q â†’ italic_A be a static data structure problem. Consider a two-party communication problem where Alice is given a query qâˆˆQğ‘ğ‘„q\in Qitalic_q âˆˆ italic_Q, Bob is given a datum dâˆˆDğ‘‘ğ·d\in Ditalic_d âˆˆ italic_D, and they have to communicate and find out the answer fâ¢(d,q)ğ‘“ğ‘‘ğ‘f(d,q)italic_f ( italic_d , italic_q ). We have the following lemma, which is a quantum analogue of a lemma of MiltersenÂ [Mil94] relating cell probe complexity to communication complexity in the classical setting.

Lemma 1

Suppose we have an (s,w,t)ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(s,w,t)( italic_s , italic_w , italic_t ) quantum cell probe solution to a static data structure problem f:DÃ—Qâ†’Anormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ·ğ‘„ğ´f:D\times Q\rightarrow Aitalic_f : italic_D Ã— italic_Q â†’ italic_A. Then we have a (2â¢t,0,logâ¡s+w,logâ¡s+w)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡0ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ´(2t,0,\log s+w,\log s+w)^{A}( 2 italic_t , 0 , roman_log italic_s + italic_w , roman_log italic_s + italic_w ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol for the corresponding communication problem. If the query scheme is address-only, we also have a (2â¢t,0,logâ¡s,logâ¡s+w)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡0ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ´(2t,0,\log s,\log s+w)^{A}( 2 italic_t , 0 , roman_log italic_s , roman_log italic_s + italic_w ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol for the corresponding communication problem. The error probability of the communication protocol is the same as that of the cell probe scheme.

Proof: Given a quantum (s,w,t)ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(s,w,t)( italic_s , italic_w , italic_t ) cell probe solution to the static data structure problem fğ‘“fitalic_f, we can get a (2â¢t,0,logâ¡s+w,logâ¡s+w)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡0ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ´(2t,0,\log s+w,\log s+w)^{A}( 2 italic_t , 0 , roman_log italic_s + italic_w , roman_log italic_s + italic_w ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol for the corresponding communication problem by just simulating the cell probe solution. If in addition, the query scheme is address-only, the messages from Alice to Bob need consist only of the â€˜addressâ€™ part. This can be seen as follows. Let the state vector of the data qubits before the iğ‘–iitalic_ith query be |Î¸iâŸ©ketsubscriptğœƒğ‘–|\theta_{i}\rangle| italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ©. |Î¸iâŸ©ketsubscriptğœƒğ‘–|\theta_{i}\rangle| italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© is independent of the query element and the stored data. Bob keeps tğ‘¡titalic_t special ancilla registers in states |Î¸iâŸ©,1â‰¤iâ‰¤tketsubscriptğœƒğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘¡|\theta_{i}\rangle,1\leq i\leq t| italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© , 1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_t at the start of the protocol Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. These special ancilla registers are in tensor with the rest of the qubits of Alice and Bob at the start of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Protocol Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P simulates the cell probe solution, but with the following modification. To simulate the iğ‘–iitalic_ith query of the cell probe solution, Alice prepares her â€˜addressâ€™ and â€˜dataâ€™ qubits as in the query scheme, but sends the â€˜addressâ€™ qubits only. Bob treats those â€˜addressâ€™ qubits together with |Î¸iâŸ©ketsubscriptğœƒğ‘–|\theta_{i}\rangle| italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© in the iğ‘–iitalic_ith special ancilla register as Aliceâ€™s query, and performs the oracle table transformation on them. He then sends these qubits (both the â€˜addressâ€™ as well as the iğ‘–iitalic_ith special register qubits) to Alice. Alice exchanges the contents of the iğ‘–iitalic_ith special register with her â€˜dataâ€™ qubits (i.e. exchanges the basis states), and proceeds with the simulation of the query scheme. This gives us a (2â¢t,0,logâ¡s,logâ¡s+w)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡0ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ´(2t,0,\log s,\log s+w)^{A}( 2 italic_t , 0 , roman_log italic_s , roman_log italic_s + italic_w ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol with the same error probability as that of the cell probe query scheme. Â 

Remark:

In many natural data structure problems logâ¡sğ‘ \log sroman_log italic_s is much smaller than wğ‘¤witalic_w and thus, in the address-only quantum case, we get a (2â¢t,0,logâ¡s,Oâ¢(w))Asuperscript2ğ‘¡0ğ‘ ğ‘‚ğ‘¤ğ´(2t,0,\log s,O(w))^{A}( 2 italic_t , 0 , roman_log italic_s , italic_O ( italic_w ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe protocol. In the classical setting of [Mil94], one gets a (2â¢t,0,logâ¡s,w)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡0ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ´(2t,0,\log s,w)^{A}( 2 italic_t , 0 , roman_log italic_s , italic_w ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT protocol. This asymmetry in message lengths is crucial in proving non-trivial lower bounds on tğ‘¡titalic_t. The concept of a safe quantum protocol helps us in exploiting this asymmetry.

We now recall some facts about the connection between cell probe schemes for predecessor and communication complexity of rank parity from [MNSW98]. We give proof sketches of these facts for completeness.

Definition 6

A (t,a,b)Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(t,a,b)^{A}( italic_t , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ((t,a,b)Bsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğµ(t,a,b)^{B}( italic_t , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) classical communication protocol is a [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ([t;l1,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) classical protocol, where assuming Alice (Bob) starts, li=asubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=aitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a for iğ‘–iitalic_i odd and li=bsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=bitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b for iğ‘–iitalic_i even (li=bsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=bitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b for iğ‘–iitalic_i odd and li=asubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=aitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a for iğ‘–iitalic_i even). A (t,c,a,b)Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(t,c,a,b)^{A}( italic_t , italic_c , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ((t,c,a,b)Bsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğµ(t,c,a,b)^{B}( italic_t , italic_c , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) quantum communication protocol is a [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ([t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) safe quantum protocol, where assuming Alice (Bob) starts, li=asubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=aitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a for iğ‘–iitalic_i odd and li=bsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=bitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b for iğ‘–iitalic_i even (li=bsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=bitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b for iğ‘–iitalic_i odd and li=asubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘l_{i}=aitalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a for iğ‘–iitalic_i even).

Definition 7 (Rank parity)

In the rank parity communication game ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,qsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Alice is given a bit string xğ‘¥xitalic_x of length pğ‘pitalic_p, Bob is given a set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of bit strings of length pğ‘pitalic_p, |S|â‰¤qğ‘†ğ‘|S|\leq q| italic_S | â‰¤ italic_q, and they have to communicate and decide whether the rank of xğ‘¥xitalic_x in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S (treating the bit strings as integers) is odd or even. By the rank of xğ‘¥xitalic_x in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, we mean the cardinality of the set {yâˆˆSâˆ£yâ‰¤x}conditional-setğ‘¦ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘¥\{y\in S\mid y\leq x\}{ italic_y âˆˆ italic_S âˆ£ italic_y â‰¤ italic_x }. In the communication game ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,q(k),Asubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğ´ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),A}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Alice is given kğ‘˜kitalic_k bit strings x1,â€¦,xksubscriptğ‘¥1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT each of length pğ‘pitalic_p, Bob is given a set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of bit strings of length pğ‘pitalic_p, |S|â‰¤qğ‘†ğ‘|S|\leq q| italic_S | â‰¤ italic_q, an index iâˆˆ[k]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘˜i\in[k]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_k ], and copies of x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; they have to communicate and decide whether the rank of xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is odd or even. In the communication game ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,q(k),Bsubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğµğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),B}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Alice is given a bit string xğ‘¥xitalic_x of length pğ‘pitalic_p and an index iâˆˆ[k]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘˜i\in[k]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_k ], Bob is given kğ‘˜kitalic_k sets S1,â€¦,Sksubscriptğ‘†1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S_{1},\ldots,S_{k}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of bit strings of length pğ‘pitalic_p, |Sj|â‰¤q,1â‰¤jâ‰¤kformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ğ‘1ğ‘—ğ‘˜|S_{j}|\leq q,1\leq j\leq k| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ italic_q , 1 â‰¤ italic_j â‰¤ italic_k; they have to communicate and decide whether the rank of xğ‘¥xitalic_x in Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is odd or even.

Fact 1

Let mğ‘šmitalic_m be a positive integer such that mğ‘šmitalic_m is a power of 2222. Suppose that there is a (nOâ¢(1),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},(\log m)^{O(1)},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) randomised (address-only quantum) cell probe scheme for the (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor problem. Then the rank parity communication game ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m,nsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\log m,n}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_m , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a (2â¢t+Oâ¢(1),Oâ¢(logâ¡n),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1))Asuperscript2ğ‘¡ğ‘‚1ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ´\left(2t+O(1),O(\log n),(\log m)^{O(1)}\right)^{A}( 2 italic_t + italic_O ( 1 ) , italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT private coin randomised (safe coinless quantum) protocol. The error probability of the communication protocol is the same as that of the cell probe scheme.

Proof: Consider the static rank parity data structure problem where the storage scheme has to store a set SâŠ†[m]ğ‘†delimited-[]ğ‘šS\subseteq[m]italic_S âŠ† [ italic_m ], |S|â‰¤nğ‘†ğ‘›|S|\leq n| italic_S | â‰¤ italic_n, and the query scheme, given a query xâˆˆ[m]ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘šx\in[m]italic_x âˆˆ [ italic_m ], has to decide whether the rank of xğ‘¥xitalic_x in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is odd or even. Fredman, KomlÃ³s and SzemerÃ©diÂ [FKS84] have shown the existence of two-level perfect hash tables containing, for each member yğ‘¦yitalic_y of the stored subset Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, yğ‘¦yitalic_yâ€™s rank in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, and using Oâ¢(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ) cells of word size Oâ¢(logâ¡m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(\log m)italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ) and requiring only Oâ¢(1)ğ‘‚1O(1)italic_O ( 1 ) deterministic cell probes. Combining a (nOâ¢(1),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},(\log m)^{O(1)},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) cell probe solution to the static predecessor problem with such a perfect hash table gives us a (nOâ¢(1)+Oâ¢(n),maxâ¡((logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),Oâ¢(logâ¡m)),t+Oâ¢(1))superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘‚1(n^{O(1)}+O(n),\max((\log m)^{O(1)},O(\log m)),t+O(1))( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_O ( italic_n ) , roman_max ( ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_O ( roman_log italic_m ) ) , italic_t + italic_O ( 1 ) ) cell probe solution to the static rank parity problem. The error probability of the cell probe scheme for the rank parity problem is the same as the error probability of the cell probe scheme for the predecessor problem. Converting the cell probe scheme for the rank parity problem into a communication protocol by [Mil94] (by LemmaÂ 1), we get a (2â¢t+Oâ¢(1),Oâ¢(logâ¡n),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1))Asuperscript2ğ‘¡ğ‘‚1ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ´(2t+O(1),O(\log n),(\log m)^{O(1)})^{A}( 2 italic_t + italic_O ( 1 ) , italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT private coin randomised (safe coinless quantum) protocol for the rank parity communication game ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m,nsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\log m,n}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_m , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The error probability of the communication protocol is the same as that of the cell probe scheme for the predecessor problem. Â 

Fact 2

Let k,pğ‘˜ğ‘k,pitalic_k , italic_p be positive integers such that kâˆ£pconditionalğ‘˜ğ‘k\mid pitalic_k âˆ£ italic_p. A communication protocol with Alice starting for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,qsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives us a communication protocol with Alice starting for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p/k,q(k),Asubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğ´ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),A}_{p/k,q}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p / italic_k , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the same message complexity, number of rounds and error probability.

Proof: Consider the problem ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p/k,q(k),Asubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğ´ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),A}_{p/k,q}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p / italic_k , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Alice, who is given x1,â€¦,xksubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, computes the concatenation x^=Î”x1â‹…x2â¢â‹¯â¢xksuperscriptÎ”^ğ‘¥â‹…subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\widehat{x}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}x_{1}\cdot x_{2}\cdots x_{k}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Bob, who is given Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, iğ‘–iitalic_i and x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, computes

S^=Î”{x1â‹…x2â¢â‹¯â¢xiâˆ’1â‹…yâ‹…0pâ¢(1âˆ’i/k):yâˆˆS}.superscriptÎ”^ğ‘†conditional-setâ‹…â‹…subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ‘¦superscript0ğ‘1ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¦ğ‘†\widehat{S}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\left\{x_{1}\cdot x_{2}\cdots x_{i-1}\cdot y\cdot 0^{p(1-i/k)}:y\in S\right\}.over^ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_y â‹… 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( 1 - italic_i / italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_y âˆˆ italic_S } .

After this, Alice and Bob run the protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,qsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on inputs x^^ğ‘¥\widehat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG, S^^ğ‘†\widehat{S}over^ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG to solve the problem ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p/k,q(k),Asubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğ´ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),A}_{p/k,q}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p / italic_k , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Â 

Fact 3

Let k,qğ‘˜ğ‘k,qitalic_k , italic_q be positive integers such that kâˆ£qconditionalğ‘˜ğ‘k\mid qitalic_k âˆ£ italic_q and kğ‘˜kitalic_k is a power of 2222. A communication protocol with Bob starting for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,qsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives us a communication protocol with Bob starting for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±pâˆ’logâ¡kâˆ’1,q/k(k),Bsubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğµğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ‘ğ‘˜\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),B}_{p-\log k-1,q/k}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - roman_log italic_k - 1 , italic_q / italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the same message complexity, number of rounds and error probability.

Proof: Consider the problem ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±pâˆ’logâ¡kâˆ’1,q/k(k),Bsubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğµğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ‘ğ‘˜\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),B}_{p-\log k-1,q/k}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - roman_log italic_k - 1 , italic_q / italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Alice, who is given xğ‘¥xitalic_x and iğ‘–iitalic_i, computes the concatenation x^=Î”(iâˆ’1)â‹…0â‹…xsuperscriptÎ”^ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘–10ğ‘¥\hat{x}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(i-1)\cdot 0\cdot xover^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP ( italic_i - 1 ) â‹… 0 â‹… italic_x. Bob, who is given S1,â€¦,Sksubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S_{1},\ldots,S_{k}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, computes the sets S1â€²,â€¦,Skâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘˜S^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{k}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where

Sjâ€²=Î”{{(jâˆ’1)â‹…0â‹…y:yâˆˆSj}ifÂ |Sj|Â is even,{(jâˆ’1)â‹…0â‹…y:yâˆˆSj}â¢â‹ƒ{(jâˆ’1)â‹…1pâˆ’logâ¡k}ifÂ |Sj|Â is odd.superscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—casesconditional-setâ‹…ğ‘—10ğ‘¦ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ifÂ |Sj|Â is evenconditional-setâ‹…ğ‘—10ğ‘¦ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—â‹…ğ‘—1superscript1ğ‘ğ‘˜ifÂ |Sj|Â is oddS^{\prime}_{j}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}\left\{(j-1)\cdot 0\cdot y:y\in S_{j}\right\}\\ ~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\mbox{if $|S_{j}|$ is even},\\ \left\{(j-1)\cdot 0\cdot y:y\in S_{j}\right\}\bigcup\left\{(j-1)\cdot 1^{p-\log k}\right\}\\ ~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\mbox{if $|S_{j}|$ is odd}.\end{array}\right.italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL { ( italic_j - 1 ) â‹… 0 â‹… italic_y : italic_y âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL if | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | is even , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL { ( italic_j - 1 ) â‹… 0 â‹… italic_y : italic_y âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } â‹ƒ { ( italic_j - 1 ) â‹… 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p - roman_log italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL if | italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | is odd . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

Above, the integers (iâˆ’1),(jâˆ’1)ğ‘–1ğ‘—1(i-1),(j-1)( italic_i - 1 ) , ( italic_j - 1 ) are to be thought of as bit strings of length logâ¡kğ‘˜\log kroman_log italic_k. Bob also computes S^=Î”â‹ƒj=1kSjâ€²superscriptÎ”^ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—\hat{S}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\bigcup_{j=1}^{k}S^{\prime}_{j}over^ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Alice and Bob then run the protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±p,qsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{p,q}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on inputs x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG, S^^ğ‘†\hat{S}over^ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG to solve the problem ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±pâˆ’logâ¡kâˆ’1,q/k(k),Bsubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘˜ğµğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ‘ğ‘˜\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(k),B}_{p-\log k-1,q/k}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - roman_log italic_k - 1 , italic_q / italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Â 

2.4 Some classical information theoretic facts

In this subsection, we discuss some classical information theoretic facts which will be used in the proof of our improved classical round elimination lemma. For a good account of classical information theory, see the book by Cover and ThomasÂ [CT91].

In this paper, all random variables have finite range and all sample spaces have finite cardinality. Let X,Y,Zğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘X,Y,Zitalic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z be random variables with some joint distribution. The Shannon entropy of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is defined as Hâ¢(X)=Î”âˆ’âˆ‘xPrâ¡[X=x]â¢logâ¡Prâ¡[X=x]superscriptÎ”ğ»ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥Prğ‘‹ğ‘¥Prğ‘‹ğ‘¥H(X)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}-\sum_{x}\Pr[X=x]\log\Pr[X=x]italic_H ( italic_X ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Pr [ italic_X = italic_x ] roman_log roman_Pr [ italic_X = italic_x ]. The mutual information of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y is defined as I(X:Y)=Î”H(X)+H(Y)âˆ’H(XY)I(X:Y)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}H(X)+H(Y)-H(XY)italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP italic_H ( italic_X ) + italic_H ( italic_Y ) - italic_H ( italic_X italic_Y ). If the range of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X has cardinality at most dğ‘‘ditalic_d, I(X:Y)â‰¤logdI(X:Y)\leq\log ditalic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) â‰¤ roman_log italic_d. I(X:Y)=0I(X:Y)=0italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) = 0 iff Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y are independent. Let I((X:Y)âˆ£Z=z)I((X:Y)\mid Z=z)italic_I ( ( italic_X : italic_Y ) âˆ£ italic_Z = italic_z ) denote the mutual information of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y conditioned on the event Z=zğ‘ğ‘§Z=zitalic_Z = italic_z.

The next fact follows easily from the definitions.

Fact 4

Let X,Y,Zğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘X,Y,Zitalic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z be random variables with some joint distribution. Then,

  1. (a)

    I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)âˆ’I(X:Y)I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)-I(X:Y)italic_I ( italic_X italic_Y : italic_Z ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Z ) + italic_I ( italic_Y : italic_Z italic_X ) - italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ). In particular, if X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y are independent I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)italic_I ( italic_X italic_Y : italic_Z ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Z ) + italic_I ( italic_Y : italic_Z italic_X ).

  2. (b)

    I(Y:ZX)=I(X:Y)+ğ„X[I((Y:Z)âˆ£X=x)]\displaystyle I(Y:ZX)=I(X:Y)+\mathop{\rm{\bf E}}_{X}[I((Y:Z)\mid X=x)]italic_I ( italic_Y : italic_Z italic_X ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) + bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_I ( ( italic_Y : italic_Z ) âˆ£ italic_X = italic_x ) ], where is expectation is over the marginal distribution of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X.

We use total variation distance to quantify the distance between two probability distributions.

Definition 8 (Total variation distance)

Let P,Qğ‘ƒğ‘„P,Qitalic_P , italic_Q be probability distributions on the same sample space Î©normal-Î©\Omegaroman_Î©. The total variation distance (also known as the â„“1subscriptnormal-â„“1\ell_{1}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-distance) between Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, denoted by â€–Pâˆ’Qâ€–1subscriptnormğ‘ƒğ‘„1\|P-Q\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_P - italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is defined as â€–Pâˆ’Qâ€–1=Î”âˆ‘xâˆˆÎ©|Pâ¢(x)âˆ’Qâ¢(x)|superscriptnormal-Î”subscriptnormğ‘ƒğ‘„1subscriptğ‘¥normal-Î©ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥\displaystyle\|P-Q\|_{1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{x\in\Omega}|P(x)-Q(x)|âˆ¥ italic_P - italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_P ( italic_x ) - italic_Q ( italic_x ) |.

We will need the average encoding theorem of Klauck, Nayak, Ta-Shma and ZuckermanÂ [KNTZ01]. Klauck et al. actually prove a quantum version of this theorem in their paper, but we will use the classical version in the proof of our round elimination lemma. Intuitively speaking, the theorem says that if the mutual information between a random variable and its randomised encoding is small, then the probability distributions on the code words for various values of the random variable are close to the average probability distribution on the code words.

Fact 5 (Average encoding theorem, [KNTZ01])

Let X,Mğ‘‹ğ‘€X,Mitalic_X , italic_M be correlated random variables. Let pxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥p_{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the (marginal) probability that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x, and Î xsuperscriptnormal-Î ğ‘¥\Pi^{x}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the conditional distribution of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M given that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let Î normal-Î \Piroman_Î  denote the (marginal) probability distribution of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M i.e. Î =âˆ‘xpxâ¢Î xnormal-Î subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptnormal-Î ğ‘¥\Pi=\sum_{x}p_{x}\Pi^{x}roman_Î  = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then,

âˆ‘xpxâ¢â€–Î xâˆ’Î â€–1â‰¤(2ln2)I(X:M).\sum_{x}p_{x}\|\Pi^{x}-\Pi\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{(2\ln 2)I(X:M)}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Î  âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) end_ARG .

A self-contained classical proof, without using quantum information theory, of this fact can be found in the appendix for completeness.

2.5 Some quantum information theoretic facts

In this subsection, we discuss some quantum information theoretic facts which will be used in the proof of our quantum round elimination lemma. For a good account of quantum information theory, see the book by Nielsen and ChuangÂ [NC00].

In this paper, all quantum systems, Hilbert spaces and superoperators are finite dimensional. Let X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y be quantum systems with some joint density matrix ÏXâ¢YsubscriptğœŒğ‘‹ğ‘Œ\rho_{XY}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X italic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If ÏXsubscriptğœŒğ‘‹\rho_{X}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the reduced density matrix of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, the von Neumann entropy of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is defined as Sâ¢(X)=Î”âˆ’TrÂ â¢ÏXâ¢logâ¡ÏXsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘†ğ‘‹TrÂ subscriptğœŒğ‘‹subscriptğœŒğ‘‹S(X)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}-\mbox{{\rm Tr} }\rho_{X}\log\rho_{X}italic_S ( italic_X ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP - Tr italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The mutual information of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y is defined as I(X:Y)=Î”S(X)+S(Y)âˆ’S(XY)I(X:Y)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}S(X)+S(Y)-S(XY)italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP italic_S ( italic_X ) + italic_S ( italic_Y ) - italic_S ( italic_X italic_Y ). If Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is at most dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional, I(X:Y)â‰¤2logdI(X:Y)\leq 2\log ditalic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) â‰¤ 2 roman_log italic_d. I(X:Y)=0I(X:Y)=0italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) = 0 iff Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y are independent i.e. ÏXâ¢Y=ÏXâŠ—ÏYsubscriptğœŒğ‘‹ğ‘Œtensor-productsubscriptğœŒğ‘‹subscriptğœŒğ‘Œ\rho_{XY}=\rho_{X}\otimes\rho_{Y}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X italic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ— italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Suppose X,Y,Zğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘X,Y,Zitalic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z are quantum systems with some joint density matrix where Zğ‘Zitalic_Z is a classical random variable i.e. the reduced density matrix of Zğ‘Zitalic_Z is diagonal in the computational basis. Let I((X:Y)âˆ£Z=z)I((X:Y)\mid Z=z)italic_I ( ( italic_X : italic_Y ) âˆ£ italic_Z = italic_z ) denote the mutual information of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y conditioned on the event Z=zğ‘ğ‘§Z=zitalic_Z = italic_z.

The next fact follows easily from the definitions.

Fact 6

Let X,Y,Z,Wğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘ŠX,Y,Z,Witalic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z , italic_W be quantum systems with some joint density matrix, where Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y are classical random variables. Then,

  1. (a)

    I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)âˆ’I(X:Y)I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)-I(X:Y)italic_I ( italic_X italic_Y : italic_Z ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Z ) + italic_I ( italic_Y : italic_Z italic_X ) - italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ). In particular, if X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y are independent I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)I(XY:Z)=I(X:Z)+I(Y:ZX)italic_I ( italic_X italic_Y : italic_Z ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Z ) + italic_I ( italic_Y : italic_Z italic_X ).

  2. (b)

    I(Y:ZX)=I(X:Y)+ğ„X[I((Y:Z)âˆ£X=x)]\displaystyle I(Y:ZX)=I(X:Y)+\mathop{\rm{\bf E}}_{X}[I((Y:Z)\mid X=x)]italic_I ( italic_Y : italic_Z italic_X ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_Y ) + bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_I ( ( italic_Y : italic_Z ) âˆ£ italic_X = italic_x ) ], where is expectation is over the marginal distribution of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X.

  3. (c)

    Suppose Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is independent of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Zğ‘Zitalic_Z is supported on mğ‘šmitalic_m qubits. Then, I(X:ZW)â‰¤2mI(X:ZW)\leq 2mitalic_I ( italic_X : italic_Z italic_W ) â‰¤ 2 italic_m.

Remarks:

1. Â Â FactÂ 6(c) is the key observation allowing us to â€œignoreâ€ the size of the â€œsafeâ€ overhead Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W in quantum round elimination applications. In these applications, the complexity of the first message in the protocol increases quickly, but the blow up is confined to the â€œsafeâ€ overhead. Earlier round reduction arguments were unable to handle this large blow up in the complexity of the first message.
2. Â Â In FactÂ 6(c), if Zğ‘Zitalic_Z is a classical random variable, we get the improved inequality I(X:ZW)â‰¤mI(X:ZW)\leq mitalic_I ( italic_X : italic_Z italic_W ) â‰¤ italic_m.

We use trace distance to quantify the distance between two density matrices.

Definition 9 (Trace distance)

Let Ï,ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho,\sigmaitalic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ be density matrices in the same Hilbert space.
