The trace distance between ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ, denoted by â€–Ïâˆ’Ïƒâ€–1subscriptnormğœŒğœ1\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_Ï - italic_Ïƒ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is defined as â€–Ïâˆ’Ïƒâ€–1=Î”TrÂ â¢(Ïâˆ’Ïƒ)â€ â¢(Ïâˆ’Ïƒ)superscriptnormal-Î”subscriptnormğœŒğœ1TrÂ superscriptğœŒğœnormal-â€ ğœŒğœ\|\rho-\sigma\|_{1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\mbox{{\rm Tr} }\sqrt{(\rho-\sigma)^{\dagger}(\rho-\sigma)}âˆ¥ italic_Ï - italic_Ïƒ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP roman_Tr square-root start_ARG ( italic_Ï - italic_Ïƒ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€  end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï - italic_Ïƒ ) end_ARG.

If ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is a density matrix in a Hilbert space â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H and â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M is a general measurement i.e. a POVM on â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H, let â„³â¢Ïâ„³ğœŒ{\cal M}\rhocaligraphic_M italic_Ï denote the probability distribution on the (classical) outcomes of â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M got by performing measurement â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M on ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï. The importance of the trace distance as a metric on density matrices stems from the following fundamental fact (see e.g.Â [AKN98]).

Fact 7

Let Ï1,Ï2subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ2\rho_{1},\rho_{2}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be two density matrices in the same Hilbert space â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. Let â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M be a POVM on â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. Then, â€–â„³â¢Ï1âˆ’â„³â¢Ï2â€–1â‰¤â€–Ï1âˆ’Ï2â€–1subscriptnormâ„³subscriptğœŒ1â„³subscriptğœŒ21subscriptnormsubscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ21\|{\cal M}\rho_{1}-{\cal M}\rho_{2}\|_{1}\leq\|\rho_{1}-\rho_{2}\|_{1}âˆ¥ caligraphic_M italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_M italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Let â„‹,ğ’¦â„‹ğ’¦{\cal H},{\cal K}caligraphic_H , caligraphic_K be disjoint Hilbert spaces such that dim(ğ’¦)â‰¥dim(â„‹)dimensionğ’¦dimensionâ„‹\dim({\cal K})\geq\dim({\cal H})roman_dim ( caligraphic_K ) â‰¥ roman_dim ( caligraphic_H ). Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï be a density matrix in â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H and |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle| italic_Ïˆ âŸ© be a pure state in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K. |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle| italic_Ïˆ âŸ© is said to be a purification of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï if TrÂ ğ’¦â¢|ÏˆâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ïˆ|=ÏsubscriptTrÂ ğ’¦ketğœ“brağœ“ğœŒ\mbox{{\rm Tr} }_{{\cal K}}|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|=\rhoTr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïˆ âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ïˆ | = italic_Ï. We will require the following basic fact about two purifications of the same density matrix.

Fact 8

Let â„‹,ğ’¦â„‹ğ’¦{\cal H},{\cal K}caligraphic_H , caligraphic_K be disjoint Hilbert spaces such that dim(ğ’¦)â‰¥dim(â„‹)dimensionğ’¦dimensionâ„‹\dim({\cal K})\geq\dim({\cal H})roman_dim ( caligraphic_K ) â‰¥ roman_dim ( caligraphic_H ). Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï be a density matrix in â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H and |ÏˆâŸ©,|Ï•âŸ©ketğœ“ketitalic-Ï•|\psi\rangle,|\phi\rangle| italic_Ïˆ âŸ© , | italic_Ï• âŸ© be two purifications of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K. Then there is a local unitary transformation Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U on ğ’¦ğ’¦{\cal K}caligraphic_K such that |ÏˆâŸ©=(IâŠ—U)â¢|Ï•âŸ©ketğœ“tensor-productğ¼ğ‘ˆketitalic-Ï•|\psi\rangle=(I\otimes U)|\phi\rangle| italic_Ïˆ âŸ© = ( italic_I âŠ— italic_U ) | italic_Ï• âŸ©, where Iğ¼Iitalic_I is the identity operator on â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H.

We now state an improved version of the quantum average encoding theorem of Klauck, Nayak, Ta-Shma and ZuckermanÂ [KNTZ01]. This improved version follows from a direct connection between fidelity and relative entropy described in [DHR78], and was also independently observed by Klauck (private communication). Intuitively speaking, the theorem says that if the mutual information between a random variable and its quantum encoding is small, then given any purifications of the quantum code words for various values of the random variable, one can find purifications of the average code word that are close to the respective purifications of the quantum code words.

Fact 9

Let X,Mğ‘‹ğ‘€X,Mitalic_X , italic_M be quantum systems with some joint density matrix. Let Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X be a classical random variable and pxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥p_{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the (marginal) probability that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H denote the Hilbert space of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M and ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the conditional density matrix of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M given that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï denote the reduced density matrix of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M. Note that Ï=âˆ‘xpxâ¢ÏxğœŒsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho=\sum_{x}p_{x}\rho^{x}italic_Ï = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let ğ’¦ğ’¦{\cal K}caligraphic_K denote a disjoint Hilbert space such that dim(ğ’¦)â‰¥dim(â„‹)dimensionğ’¦dimensionâ„‹\dim({\cal K})\geq\dim({\cal H})roman_dim ( caligraphic_K ) â‰¥ roman_dim ( caligraphic_H ). Let |ÏˆxâŸ©ketsuperscriptğœ“ğ‘¥|\psi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© be purifications of ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K. Then there exist purifications |Ï•xâŸ©ketsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥|\phi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K such that

âˆ‘xpxâ¢â€–|ÏˆxâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ïˆx|âˆ’|Ï•xâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ï•x|â€–1â‰¤(4ln2)I(X:M).\sum_{x}p_{x}\||\psi^{x}\rangle\langle\psi^{x}|-|\phi^{x}\rangle\langle\phi^{x}|\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{(4\ln 2)I(X:M)}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ | italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | - | italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG ( 4 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) end_ARG .

A proof of this fact can be found in the appendix for completeness.

3 Reducing the number of rounds

In this section, we prove an intermediate result which will be required to prove our strong round elimination lemmas. In SectionÂ 3.1 we prove the intermediate result in its classical version (LemmaÂ 2), whereas in SectionÂ 3.2 we prove the intermediate result in its quantum version (LemmaÂ 3). The proof of LemmaÂ 2 is similar to the proof of LemmaÂ 4.4 in [KNTZ01] (see also [Man01]), but much simpler since we are in the classical setting. The proof of LemmaÂ 3 is a slight refinement of the proof of LemmaÂ 4.4 in Â [KNTZ01], and is included here for completeness. Intuitively speaking, the intermediate result says that if the first message in a communication protocol carries little information about the senderâ€™s input, under some probability distribution on Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs, then it can be eliminated, giving rise to a protocol where the other player starts, with one less round of communication, smaller message complexity, and with similar average error probability with respect to the same probability distribution on Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs.

Consider a communication protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P computing a function f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µ:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z. For an input (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y, we define the error Ïµx,yğ’«subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\epsilon^{{\cal P}}_{x,y}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P on (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) to be the probability that the result of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P on input (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) is not equal to fâ¢(x,y)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦f(x,y)italic_f ( italic_x , italic_y ). For a protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, given a probability distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D on ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y, we define the average error ÏµDğ’«subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«ğ·\epsilon^{{\cal P}}_{D}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P with respect to Dğ·Ditalic_D as the expectation over Dğ·Ditalic_D of the error of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P on inputs (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y. We define Ïµğ’«superscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«\epsilon^{\cal P}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be the maximum error of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P on inputs (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y i.e. Ïµğ’«superscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«\epsilon^{\cal P}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the error of protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P.

3.1 Classical

Lemma 2

Suppose f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µnormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z is a function. Let Dğ·Ditalic_D be a probability distribution on ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y, and ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P be a [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT private coin randomised protocol for fğ‘“fitalic_f. Let Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X stand for the classical random variable denoting Aliceâ€™s input, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M stand for the random variable denoting the first message of Alice in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, and I(X:M)I(X:M)italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) denote the mutual information between Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Mğ‘€Mitalic_M when the inputs to ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P are distributed according to Dğ·Ditalic_D. Then there exists a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT deterministic protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q for fğ‘“fitalic_f, such that ÏµDğ’¬â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((2ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{\cal Q}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}+(1/2)((2\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: We first give an overview of the idea of the proof before getting down to the details. The proof proceeds in stages.

Idea of Stage 1:

Starting from protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, we construct a [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT private coin protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where the first message is independent of Aliceâ€™s input, and ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((2ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal P}}_{D}+(1/2)((2\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The important idea here is to first generate Aliceâ€™s message using a new private coin without â€˜lookingâ€™ at her input, and after that, to adjust Aliceâ€™s old private coin in a suitable manner so as to be consistent with her message and input.

Idea of Stage 2:

Since the first message of ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is independent of Aliceâ€™s input, Bob can generate it himself. Doing this and setting coin tosses appropriately gives us a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT deterministic protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q for fğ‘“fitalic_f such that ÏµDğ’¬â‰¤ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((2ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{\cal Q}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}+(1/2)((2\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.


We now give the details of the proof. Let Î xsuperscriptÎ ğ‘¥\Pi^{x}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the probability distribution of the first message Mğ‘€Mitalic_M of protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P when Aliceâ€™s input X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Define Î =Î”âˆ‘xdxâ¢Î xsuperscriptÎ”Î subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¥superscriptÎ ğ‘¥\Pi\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{x}d_{x}\Pi^{x}roman_Î  start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where dxsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¥d_{x}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the marginal probability of X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x under distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D. Î Î \Piroman_Î  is the probability distribution of the average first message of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P under distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D. For xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in{\cal X}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X and an instance mğ‘šmitalic_m of the first message of Alice, let qrxâ¢msubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘Ÿq^{xm}_{r}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the conditional probability that the private coin toss of Alice results in rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, given that Aliceâ€™s input is xğ‘¥xitalic_x and her first message in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P is mğ‘šmitalic_m. If in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P message mğ‘šmitalic_m cannot occur when Aliceâ€™s input is xğ‘¥xitalic_x, then we define qrxâ¢m=Î”0superscriptÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘Ÿ0q^{xm}_{r}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}0italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP 0. Let Ï€mxsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥\pi_{m}^{x}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the probability that the first message of Alice in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P is mğ‘šmitalic_m, given that her input is xğ‘¥xitalic_x. Let Ï€msubscriptğœ‹ğ‘š\pi_{m}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the probability that the first message of Alice in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P is mğ‘šmitalic_m, when Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs are distributed according to Dğ·Ditalic_D. Then, Ï€m=âˆ‘xdxâ¢Ï€mxsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥\pi_{m}=\sum_{x}d_{x}\pi_{m}^{x}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Stage 1:

We construct a [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT private coin randomised protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for fğ‘“fitalic_f with average error under distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((2ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}+(1/2)((2\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and where the probability distribution of the first message is independent of the input to Alice. We now describe the protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Suppose Alice is given xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in{\cal X}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X and Bob is given yâˆˆğ’´ğ‘¦ğ’´y\in{\cal Y}italic_y âˆˆ caligraphic_Y. Alice tosses a fresh private coin to pick mğ‘šmitalic_m with probability Ï€msubscriptğœ‹ğ‘š\pi_{m}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and set her old private coin to rğ‘Ÿritalic_r with probability qrxâ¢msubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘Ÿq^{xm}_{r}italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. After this, Alice and Bob behave as in protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P (henceforth, Alice ignores the new private coin which she had tossed to generate her first message mğ‘šmitalic_m). Hence in ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the probability distribution of the first message is independent of Aliceâ€™s input.

Let us now compare the situations in protocols ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P and ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when Aliceâ€™s input is xğ‘¥xitalic_x, Bobâ€™s input is yğ‘¦yitalic_y, Alice has finished tossing her private coins (both old and new), but no communication has taken place as yet. In protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, the probability that Aliceâ€™s private coin toss results in rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is âˆ‘mÏ€mxâ¢qrxâ¢msubscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘Ÿ\sum_{m}\pi_{m}^{x}q^{xm}_{r}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the probability that Aliceâ€™s old private coin is set to rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is âˆ‘mÏ€mâ¢qrxâ¢msubscriptğ‘šsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘Ÿ\sum_{m}\pi_{m}q^{xm}_{r}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, the total variation distance between the probability distributions on Aliceâ€™s old private coin is

=\displaystyle== âˆ‘m|Ï€mxâˆ’Ï€m|subscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptğœ‹ğ‘š\displaystyle\sum_{m}\left|\pi_{m}^{x}-\pi_{m}\right|âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |
=\displaystyle== â€–Î xâˆ’Î â€–1.subscriptnormsuperscriptÎ ğ‘¥Î 1\displaystyle\|\Pi^{x}-\Pi\|_{1}.âˆ¥ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Î  âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Hence, the error probability of ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on input x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,yitalic_x , italic_y Ïµx,yğ’«â€²â‰¤Ïµx,yğ’«+(1/2)â¢â€–Î xâˆ’Î â€–1subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«ğ‘¥ğ‘¦12subscriptnormsuperscriptÎ ğ‘¥Î 1\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{x,y}\leq\epsilon^{\cal P}_{x,y}+(1/2)\|\Pi^{x}-\Pi\|_{1}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) âˆ¥ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Î  âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. â‰¤\displaystyle\leqâ‰¤ ÏµDğ’«+12((2ln2)I(X:M))1/2.\displaystyle\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}+\frac{1}{2}((2\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}.italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The last inequality follows from FactÂ 5.

Stage 2:

We now construct our desired [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT deterministic protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q for fğ‘“fitalic_f with ÏµDğ’¬â‰¤ÏµDğ’«â€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’¬ğ·subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ·\epsilon^{\cal Q}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Suppose all the coin tosses of Alice and Bob in ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are done publicly before any communication takes place. Now there is no need for the first message from Alice to Bob, because Bob can reconstruct the message by looking at the public coin tosses. This gives us a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin protocol ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Ïµx,yğ’¬â€²=Ïµx,yğ’«â€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’¬â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\epsilon^{{\cal Q}^{\prime}}_{x,y}=\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{x,y}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y. By setting the public coin tosses of ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to an appropriate value, we get a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT deterministic protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q such that ÏµDğ’¬â‰¤ÏµDğ’¬â€²=ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((2ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{\cal Q}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal Q}^{\prime}}_{D}=\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}+(1/2)((2\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

This completes the proof of LemmaÂ 2. Â 

3.2 Quantum

Lemma 3

Suppose f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µnormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z is a function. Let Dğ·Ditalic_D be a probability distribution on ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y, and ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P be a [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol for fğ‘“fitalic_f. Let Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X stand for the classical random variable denoting Aliceâ€™s input, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M denote the first message of Alice in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, and I(X:M)I(X:M)italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) denote the mutual information between Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and Mğ‘€Mitalic_M when the inputs to ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P are distributed according to Dğ·Ditalic_D. Then there exists a [tâˆ’1;c+l1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;c+l_{1};l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_c + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q for fğ‘“fitalic_f, such that ÏµDğ’¬â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((4ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{\cal Q}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}+(1/2)((4\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 4 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: We first give an overview of the plan of the proof, before getting down to the details. The proof proceeds in stages. StageÂ 1 of the quantum proof corresponds to StageÂ 1 of the classical proof, and StagesÂ 2A and 2B of the quantum proof together correspond to StageÂ 2 of the classical proof.

Idea of Stage 1:

Starting from protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, we construct a [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where the first message is independent of Aliceâ€™s input, and ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((4ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal P}}_{D}+(1/2)((4\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 4 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The important idea here is to generate a purification |Ï•xâŸ©ketsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥|\phi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© of the average first message ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï of Alice in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P that is close to the purification |ÏˆxâŸ©ketsuperscriptğœ“ğ‘¥|\psi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© of the message ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Alice in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P when her input is xğ‘¥xitalic_x. The existence of such a purification |Ï•xâŸ©ketsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥|\phi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© is guaranteed by FactÂ 9.

Idea of Stage 2A:

Since the first message of ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is independent of Aliceâ€™s input (in fact its density matrix is ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï), Bob can generate it himself. This suffices if ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a one-round protocol, and completes the proof of LemmaÂ 3 for such protocols. But if ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has more than one round, it is also necessary for Bob to achieve the correct entanglement between Aliceâ€™s work qubits and the first message i.e. it is necessary that the joint state of Aliceâ€™s work qubits and the qubits of the first message be |Ï•xâŸ©ketsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥|\phi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ©. Bob achieves this by first sending a safe message of l1+csubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘l_{1}+citalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c qubits. If Aliceâ€™s input is xğ‘¥xitalic_x, she then applies a unitary transformation Vxsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¥V_{x}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on her work qubits in order to make the joint state of her work qubits and the qubits of the first message |Ï•xâŸ©ketsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥|\phi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ©. The existence of such a Vxsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¥V_{x}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows from FactÂ 8. Doing all this gives us a [t+1;c+l1;0,0,l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™100subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t+1;c+l_{1};0,0,l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t + 1 ; italic_c + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; 0 , 0 , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for fğ‘“fitalic_f such that Ïµx,yğ’¬â€²=Ïµx,yğ’«â€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’¬â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\epsilon^{{\cal Q}^{\prime}}_{x,y}=\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{x,y}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y.

Idea of Stage 2B:

Since the first message of Alice in ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is zero qubits long, Bob can concatenate his first two messages, giving us a [tâˆ’1;c+l1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;c+l_{1};l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_c + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q for fğ‘“fitalic_f such that Ïµx,yğ’¬=Ïµx,yğ’¬â€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’¬ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’¬â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\epsilon^{{\cal Q}}_{x,y}=\epsilon^{{\cal Q}^{\prime}}_{x,y}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y. The technical reason behind this is that unitary transformations on disjoint sets of qubits commute. Note that ÏµDğ’¬=ÏµDğ’¬â€²=ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((4ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{{\cal Q}}_{D}=\epsilon^{{\cal Q}^{\prime}}_{D}=\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal P}}_{D}+(1/2)((4\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 4 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We now give the details of the proof. Let ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the density matrix of the first message Mğ‘€Mitalic_M of protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P when Aliceâ€™s input X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B denote Aliceâ€™s work qubits excluding the qubits of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M and Bobâ€™s work qubits respectively. Let |ÏˆxâŸ©Aâ¢Msubscriptketsuperscriptğœ“ğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘€|\psi^{x}\rangle_{AM}| italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the joint pure state of Aâ¢Mğ´ğ‘€AMitalic_A italic_M in ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P when Aliceâ€™s input X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x, she has finished preparing her first message, but no communication has taken place as yet. Without loss of generality, the number of qubits in Ağ´Aitalic_A is at least the number of qubits in Mğ‘€Mitalic_M. Define Ï=Î”âˆ‘xpxâ¢ÏxsuperscriptÎ”ğœŒsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{x}p_{x}\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where pxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥p_{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the marginal probability of X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x under distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D. ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is the density matrix of the average first message of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P under distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D.

Stage 1:

We construct a [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for fğ‘“fitalic_f with average error under distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D ÏµDğ’«â€²â‰¤ÏµDğ’«+(1/2)((4ln2)I(X:M))1/2\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\prime}}_{D}\leq\epsilon^{{\cal P}}_{D}+(1/2)((4\ln 2)I(X:M))^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 / 2 ) ( ( 4 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and where the density matrix of the first message is independent of the input xğ‘¥xitalic_x to Alice. Stage 2A:

The existence of such a Vxsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¥V_{x}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows from FactÂ 8. The global state of Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s qubits at this point in protocol ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the same as the global state of Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s qubits at the point in protocol ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT just after Alice has sent her first message to Bob. Bob now treats Mğ‘€Mitalic_M as if it were the first message of Alice in ğ’«â€²superscriptğ’«â€²{\cal P}^{\prime}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and proceeds to compute his response Nğ‘Nitalic_N (the qubits of Nğ‘Nitalic_N are a subset of the qubits of Mâ¢Bğ‘€ğµMBitalic_M italic_B) of length l2subscriptğ‘™2l_{2}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Bob starts the communication, the communication goes on for t+1ğ‘¡1t+1italic_t + 1 rounds, the first message of Bob of length l1+csubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘l_{1}+citalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c viz. A2subscriptğ´2A_{2}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a safe message, and the first message of Alice is zero qubits long.

Stage 2B:

We finally construct our desired [tâˆ’1;c+l1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;c+l_{1};l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_c + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q for fğ‘“fitalic_f with Ïµx,yğ’¬=Ïµx,yğ’¬â€²subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’¬ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’¬â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\epsilon^{{\cal Q}}_{x,y}=\epsilon^{{\cal Q}^{\prime}}_{x,y}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for all (x,y)âˆˆğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ’³ğ’´(x,y)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}( italic_x , italic_y ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y. In protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q Bob, after doing the same computations as in ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, first sends as a single message the (l1+c)+l2subscriptğ‘™1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™2(l_{1}+c)+l_{2}( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ) + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT qubits A2â¢Nsubscriptğ´2ğ‘A_{2}Nitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N. After receiving A2â¢Nsubscriptğ´2ğ‘A_{2}Nitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N, Alice applies Vxsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¥V_{x}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on Ağ´Aitalic_A followed by her appropriate unitary transformation on Aâ¢Nğ´ğ‘ANitalic_A italic_N viz. the unitary transformation of Alice in ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the qubits of Aâ¢Nğ´ğ‘ANitalic_A italic_N after she has received the first two messages of Bob. The global state of all the qubits of Alice and Bob at this point in protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q is the same as the global state of all the qubits of Alice and Bob at the point in protocol ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT just after Alice has finished generating her second message but before she has sent it to Bob. This is because unitary transformations on disjoint sets of qubits commute. After this, protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q proceeds as protocol ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²{\cal Q}^{\prime}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q Bob starts the communication, the communication goes on for tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1italic_t - 1 rounds, and the first message of Bob of length (l1+c)+l2subscriptğ‘™1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™2(l_{1}+c)+l_{2}( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ) + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT viz. A2â¢Nsubscriptğ´2ğ‘A_{2}Nitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N contains a safe overhead viz. A2subscriptğ´2A_{2}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of l1+csubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘l_{1}+citalic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c qubits.

This completes the proof of LemmaÂ 3. Â 

Remark:

The proof of LemmaÂ 3 requires the global state of all the qubits of Alice and Bob to be pure at all times during the execution of protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P, when Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs are in computational basis states. This is because we use the machinery of purifications in the proof. The proof also ensures that the purity property holds for the final protocol ğ’¬ğ’¬{\cal Q}caligraphic_Q.

4 The round elimination lemma

We now prove the classical and quantum versions of our strong round elimination lemma in SectionsÂ 4.1 and 4.2 respectively. The round elimination lemma is stated for public coin protocols only. Since a public coin classical randomised protocol can be converted to a private coin classical randomised protocol at the expense of an additive increase in the communication complexity by at most logarithm of the total bit size of the inputsÂ [New91], we also get a similar round elimination lemma for private coin classical randomised protocols. A similar statement about round elimination can be made for safe coinless quantum protocols; for such protocols the safe overhead increases by an additional additive term that is at most logarithm of the total bit size of the inputs. But since the statement of the round elimination lemma is cleanest for public coin protocols, we give it below for such protocols only.

4.1 Classical

Lemma 4 (Round elimination lemma, classical version)

Suppose f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µnormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z is a function. Suppose the communication game f(n),Asuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ´f^{(n),A}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol with error less than Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. Proof: Suppose the given protocol for f(n),Asuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ´f^{(n),A}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has error Î´~<Î´~ğ›¿ğ›¿\tilde{\delta}<\deltaover~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG < italic_Î´. Define Ïµ~=Î”Î´~+(1/2)â¢(2â¢l1â¢lnâ¡2/n)1/2superscriptÎ”~italic-Ïµ~ğ›¿12superscript2subscriptğ‘™12ğ‘›12\tilde{\epsilon}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\tilde{\delta}+(1/2)(2l_{1}\ln 2/n)^{1/2}over~ start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG + ( 1 / 2 ) ( 2 italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ln 2 / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To prove the round elimination lemma it suffices to give, by the harder direction of Yaoâ€™s minimax lemmaÂ [Yao77], for any probability distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D on ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y, a [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT deterministic protocol ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P for fğ‘“fitalic_f with ÏµDğ’«â‰¤Ïµ~<Ïµsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«ğ·~italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}\leq\tilde{\epsilon}<\epsilonitalic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ over~ start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG < italic_Ïµ. To this end, we will first construct a probability distribution Dâˆ—superscriptğ·âˆ—D^{\ast}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on ğ’³nÃ—[n]Ã—ğ’´superscriptğ’³ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ’´{\cal X}^{n}\times[n]\times{\cal Y}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— [ italic_n ] Ã— caligraphic_Y as follows: Choose iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] uniformly at random. Using FactÂ 4 and the fact that under distribution Dâˆ—superscriptğ·âˆ—D^{\ast}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT X1,â€¦,Xnsubscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are independent random variables, we get that

ğ„i,X[I((Xi:M)âˆ£X1,â€¦,Xiâˆ’1=x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1)]=ğ„i[I(Xi:MX1â‹¯Xiâˆ’1)]=I(X:M)nâ‰¤l1n.\begin{array}[]{lrl}\mathop{\rm{\bf E}}_{i,X}\,[I((X_{i}:M)\mid X_{1},\ldots,X_{i-1}=x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1})]&=&\displaystyle\mathop{\rm{\bf E}}_{i}\,[I(X_{i}:MX_{1}\cdots X_{i-1})]\\ &=&\frac{I(X:M)}{n}\\ &\leq&\frac{l_{1}}{n}.\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_I ( ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_M ) âˆ£ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] end_CELL start_CELL = end_CELL start_CELL bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_I ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_M italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = end_CELL start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL â‰¤ end_CELL start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY (1)

Also,

Î´~â‰¥ÏµDâˆ—ğ’«âˆ—=ğ„i,X[ÏµDâˆ—;i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1ğ’«âˆ—].~ğ›¿subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’«âˆ—superscriptğ·âˆ—subscriptğ„ğ‘–ğ‘‹delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğ’«âˆ—superscriptğ·âˆ—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1\tilde{\delta}\geq\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\ast}}_{D^{\ast}}=\mathop{\rm{\bf E}}_{i,X}\,\left[\epsilon^{{\cal P}^{\ast}}_{D^{\ast};i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}\right].over~ start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG â‰¥ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . (2)

Above, the expectations are under distribution Dâˆ—superscriptğ·âˆ—D^{\ast}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the mutual informations are for protocol ğ’«âˆ—superscriptğ’«âˆ—{\cal P}^{\ast}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with its inputs distributed according to Dâˆ—superscriptğ·âˆ—D^{\ast}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

For any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1âˆˆğ’³subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ’³x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}\in{\cal X}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X, let us now define the [t;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘™1â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT private coin randomised protocol ğ’«i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1{\cal P}^{\prime}_{i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the function fğ‘“fitalic_f in terms of protocol ğ’«âˆ—superscriptğ’«âˆ—{\cal P}^{\ast}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as follows: Alice is given xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in{\cal X}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_X and Bob is given yâˆˆğ’´ğ‘¦ğ’´y\in{\cal Y}italic_y âˆˆ caligraphic_Y. The first inequality follows from (5), the second inequality follows from the concavity of the square root function and the last inequality from (1) and (2).

Thus, we can immediately see that there exist iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] and x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1âˆˆğ’³subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ’³x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}\in{\cal X}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X such that ÏµDğ’«i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1â‰¤Ïµ~subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ’«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ·~italic-Ïµ\epsilon^{{\cal P}_{i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}}_{D}\leq\tilde{\epsilon}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ over~ start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG. Let ğ’«=Î”ğ’«i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1superscriptÎ”ğ’«subscriptğ’«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1{\cal P}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}{\cal P}_{i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}caligraphic_P start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}caligraphic_P is our desired [tâˆ’1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT deterministic protocol for fğ‘“fitalic_f with ÏµDğ’«â‰¤Ïµ~subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ’«ğ·~italic-Ïµ\epsilon^{\cal P}_{D}\leq\tilde{\epsilon}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ over~ start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG, thus completing the proof of the round elimination lemma. Â 

4.2 Quantum

Lemma 5 (Round elimination lemma, quantum version)

Suppose f:ğ’³Ã—ğ’´â†’ğ’µnormal-:ğ‘“normal-â†’ğ’³ğ’´ğ’µf:{\cal X}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow{\cal Z}italic_f : caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_Y â†’ caligraphic_Z is a function. Suppose the communication game f(n),Asuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ´f^{(n),A}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a [t;c;l1,â€¦,lt]Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ´[t;c;l_{1},\ldots,l_{t}]^{A}[ italic_t ; italic_c ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe public coin quantum protocol with error less than Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. Then there is a [tâˆ’1;c+l1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;c+l_{1};l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_c + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe public coin quantum protocol for fğ‘“fitalic_f with error less than Ïµ=Î”Î´+(1/2)â¢(8â¢l1â¢lnâ¡2/n)1/2superscriptnormal-Î”italic-Ïµğ›¿12superscript8subscriptğ‘™12ğ‘›12\epsilon\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\delta+(1/2)(8l_{1}\ln 2/n)^{1/2}italic_Ïµ start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Î´ + ( 1 / 2 ) ( 8 italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ln 2 / italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: (Sketch) The proof is very similar to the proof of LemmaÂ 4. We just point out some important things below. Note that in the quantum setting, the upper bound in (1) is 2â¢l1n2subscriptğ‘™1ğ‘›\frac{2l_{1}}{n}divide start_ARG 2 italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG by FactÂ 6(c). Also, in the definition of protocol ğ’«i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1{\cal P}^{\prime}_{i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, instead of feeding probabilistic mixtures for the inputs Xi+1,â€¦,Xnsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{i+1},\ldots,X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Alice feeds appropriate pure states (pure states that would give the correct probabilistic mixture were they to be measured in the computational basis). EquationsÂ 3 and 4 continue to hold because protocol ğ’«âˆ—superscriptğ’«âˆ—{\cal P}^{\ast}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is secure. Since the global state of all the qubits of Alice and Bob is pure at all times during the execution of protocol ğ’«i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’«â€²ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1{\cal P}^{\prime}_{i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when Aliceâ€™s and Bobâ€™s inputs are in computational basis states, LemmaÂ 3 can now be used to get the [tâˆ’1;c+l1;l2,â€¦,lt]Bsuperscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2â€¦subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡ğµ[t-1;c+l_{1};l_{2},\ldots,l_{t}]^{B}[ italic_t - 1 ; italic_c + italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT safe coinless quantum protocol ğ’«i;x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1subscriptğ’«ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1{\cal P}_{i;x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for fğ‘“fitalic_f. Â 

5 Optimal lower bounds for predecessor

In this section, we prove our (optimal) lower bounds on the query complexity of static predecessor searching in the cell probe model with randomised or address-only quantum query schemes.

Theorem 1

Suppose there is a (nOâ¢(1),(logâ¡m)Oâ¢(1),t)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‚1ğ‘¡(n^{O(1)},(\log m)^{O(1)},t)( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t ) randomised cell probe scheme for the (m,n)ğ‘šğ‘›(m,n)( italic_m , italic_n )-static predecessor problem with error probability less than 1/3131/31 / 3. Then,

  1. (a)

    t=Î©â¢(logâ¡logâ¡mlogâ¡logâ¡logâ¡m)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘šğ‘št=\Omega\left(\frac{\log\log m}{\log\log\log m}\right)italic_t = roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG ) as a function of mğ‘šmitalic_m;

  2. (b)

    t=Î©â¢(logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘¡Î©ğ‘›ğ‘›t=\Omega\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log n}{\log\log n}}\,\right)italic_t = roman_Î© ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG end_ARG ) as a function of nğ‘›nitalic_n.

The same lower bound also holds for address-only quantum cell probe schemes for static predecessor searching.

Proof: The proof is similar to the proof of the lower bound for predecessor in [MNSW98], but with different parameters, and using our stronger round elimination lemma in its classical version (LemmaÂ 4).

By FactÂ 1, it suffices to consider communication protocols for the rank parity communication game ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m,nsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\log m,n}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_m , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let n=2(logâ¡logâ¡m)2/logâ¡logâ¡logâ¡mğ‘›superscript2superscriptğ‘š2ğ‘šn=2^{(\log\log m)^{2}/\log\log\log m}italic_n = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / roman_log roman_log roman_log italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let c1=Î”(2â¢lnâ¡2)â¢62superscriptÎ”subscriptğ‘122superscript62c_{1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(2\ln 2)6^{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) 6 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For any given constants c2,c3â‰¥1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘31c_{2},c_{3}\geq 1italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 1, define

a=Î”c2â¢logâ¡nb=Î”(logâ¡m)c3formulae-sequencesuperscriptÎ”ğ‘subscriptğ‘2ğ‘›superscriptÎ”ğ‘superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘3a\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}c_{2}\log n~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}b\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(\log m)^{c_{3}}italic_a start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_n italic_b start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
t=Î”logâ¡logâ¡m(c1+c2+c3)â¢logâ¡logâ¡logâ¡m.superscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3ğ‘št\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\frac{\log\log m}{(c_{1}+c_{2}+c_{3})\log\log\log m}.italic_t start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP divide start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_log roman_log roman_log italic_m end_ARG .

We will show that ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m,nsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\log m,n}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_m , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not have (2â¢t,a,b)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(2t,a,b)^{A}( 2 italic_t , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised communication protocols with error less than 1/3131/31 / 3, thus proving both the desired lower bounds for the predecessor problem.

Given a (2â¢t,a,b)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(2t,a,b)^{A}( 2 italic_t , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m,nsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\log m,n}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_m , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with error probability at most Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´, we can get a (2â¢t,a,b)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(2t,a,b)^{A}( 2 italic_t , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡mc1â¢aâ¢t2,n(c1â¢aâ¢t2),Asubscriptsuperscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ´ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}^{(c_{1}at^{2}),A}_{\frac{\log m}{c_{1}at^{2}},n}PAR start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with error probability at most Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ by FactÂ 2. Using LemmaÂ 4 again, we get a (2â¢tâˆ’2,a,b)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡2ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(2t-2,a,b)^{A}( 2 italic_t - 2 , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m2â¢c1â¢aâ¢t2,nc1â¢bâ¢t2subscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘š2subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\frac{\log m}{2c_{1}at^{2}},\frac{n}{c_{1}bt^{2}}}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but the error probability increases to at most Î´+2â¢(12â¢t)âˆ’1ğ›¿2superscript12ğ‘¡1\delta+2(12t)^{-1}italic_Î´ + 2 ( 12 italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We do the above steps repeatedly. We start off with a (2â¢t,a,b)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(2t,a,b)^{A}( 2 italic_t , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m,nsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šğ‘›\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\log m,n}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_m , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with error probability less than 1/3131/31 / 3. After applying the above steps iğ‘–iitalic_i times, we get a (2â¢tâˆ’2â¢i,a,b)Asuperscript2ğ‘¡2ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(2t-2i,a,b)^{A}( 2 italic_t - 2 italic_i , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin protocol for ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m(2â¢c1â¢aâ¢t2)i,n(c1â¢bâ¢t2)isubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šsuperscript2subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘–\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\frac{\log m}{(2c_{1}at^{2})^{i}},\frac{n}{(c_{1}bt^{2})^{i}}}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG ( 2 italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with error probability less than 1/3+2â¢iâ¢(12â¢t)âˆ’1132ğ‘–superscript12ğ‘¡11/3+2i(12t)^{-1}1 / 3 + 2 italic_i ( 12 italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

By applying the above steps tğ‘¡titalic_t times, we finally get a (0,a,b)Asuperscript0ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(0,a,b)^{A}( 0 , italic_a , italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol for the problem ğ–¯ğ– ğ–±logâ¡m(2â¢c1â¢aâ¢t2)t,n(c1â¢bâ¢t2)tsubscriptğ–¯ğ– ğ–±ğ‘šsuperscript2subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘¡ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘¡\mbox{{\sf PAR}}_{\frac{\log m}{(2c_{1}at^{2})^{t}},\frac{n}{(c_{1}bt^{2})^{t}}}PAR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG ( 2 italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with error probability less than 1/3+2â¢tâ¢(12â¢t)âˆ’1=1/2132ğ‘¡superscript12ğ‘¡1121/3+2t(12t)^{-1}=1/21 / 3 + 2 italic_t ( 12 italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 / 2. From the given values of the parameters, we see that logâ¡m(2â¢c1â¢aâ¢t2)tâ‰¥(logâ¡m)Î©â¢(1)ğ‘šsuperscript2subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘šÎ©1\frac{\log m}{(2c_{1}at^{2})^{t}}\geq(\log m)^{\Omega(1)}divide start_ARG roman_log italic_m end_ARG start_ARG ( 2 italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¥ ( roman_log italic_m ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and n(c1â¢bâ¢t2)tâ‰¥nÎ©â¢(1)ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›Î©1\frac{n}{(c_{1}bt^{2})^{t}}\geq n^{\Omega(1)}divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¥ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus, we get a zero round protocol for a rank parity problem on a non-trivial domain with error probability less than 1/2121/21 / 2, which is a contradiction.

In the above proof, we are tacitly ignoring â€œrounding offâ€ problems. We remark that this does not affect the correctness of the proof.

Finally we observe that by using LemmaÂ 3, one can prove that the same lower bound holds for address-only quantum cell probe schemes for static predecessor. Â 

6 The â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem

We illustrate another application of the round elimination lemma to communication complexity by proving improved rounds versus communication tradeoffs for the â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem.

Theorem 2

The bounded error public coin randomised tğ‘¡titalic_t-round communication complexity of ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is lower bounded by Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢tâˆ’2)normal-Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡2\Omega(n^{1/t}t^{-2})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). For bounded error quantum protocols with input-independent prior entanglement for ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have a lower bound of Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢tâˆ’1)normal-Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡1\Omega(n^{1/t}t^{-1})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Proof: We recall the following reduction from ğ–¦ğ–³n/k(k),Asuperscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ´\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n/k}^{(k),A}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n / italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see [MNSW98]): In ğ–¦ğ–³n/k(k),Asuperscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ´\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n/k}^{(k),A}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n / italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Alice is given x1,â€¦,xkâˆˆ{0,1}n/ksubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscript01ğ‘›ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\in\{0,1\}^{n/k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Bob is given iâˆˆ[k]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘˜i\in[k]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_k ], yâˆˆ{0,1}n/kğ‘¦superscript01ğ‘›ğ‘˜y\in\{0,1\}^{n/k}italic_y âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and copies of x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and they have to communicate and decide if xi>ysubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¦x_{i}>yitalic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_y. To reduce ğ–¦ğ–³n/k(k),Asuperscriptsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ´\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n/k}^{(k),A}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n / italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Alice constructs x^âˆˆ{0,1}n^ğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›\hat{x}\in\{0,1\}^{n}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by concatenating x1,â€¦,xksubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Bob constructs y^âˆˆ{0,1}n^ğ‘¦superscript01ğ‘›\hat{y}\in\{0,1\}^{n}over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by concatenating x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1,y,1nâ¢(1âˆ’i/k)subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ‘¦superscript1ğ‘›1ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1},y,1^{n(1-i/k)}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y , 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ( 1 - italic_i / italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It is easy to see that x^>y^^ğ‘¥^ğ‘¦\hat{x}>\hat{y}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG > over^ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG iff xi>ysubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¦x_{i}>yitalic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_y.

Suppose there is a tğ‘¡titalic_t-round bounded error public coin randomised protocol for ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with communication complexity cğ‘citalic_c. We can think of the protocol as a (t,c,c)Asuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘ğ´(t,c,c)^{A}( italic_t , italic_c , italic_c ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT public coin randomised protocol with error probability less than 1/3131/31 / 3. Suppose nâ‰¥ktğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡n\geq k^{t}italic_n â‰¥ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where k=Î”(2â¢lnâ¡2)â¢(3â¢t)2â¢csuperscriptÎ”ğ‘˜22superscript3ğ‘¡2ğ‘k\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}(2\ln 2)(3t)^{2}citalic_k start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) ( 3 italic_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c. Applying the self-reduction and LemmaÂ 4 alternately for tğ‘¡titalic_t stages gives us a zero round protocol for the â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem on a non-trivial domain with error probability less than 1/2121/21 / 2, which is a contradiction. Thus, c=Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢tâˆ’2)ğ‘Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡2c=\Omega(n^{1/t}t^{-2})italic_c = roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

In the above proof, we are tacitly ignoring â€œrounding offâ€ problems. We remark that this does not affect the correctness of the proof.

Finally, we observe that for bounded error quantum protocols with input-independent prior entanglement for ğ–¦ğ–³nsubscriptğ–¦ğ–³ğ‘›\mbox{{\sf GT}}_{n}GT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one can improve the lower bound to Î©â¢(n1/tâ¢tâˆ’1)Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡1\Omega(n^{1/t}t^{-1})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by exploiting the fact that by definition, a quantum protocol sends fixed length messages independent of the input. Â 

7 Conclusion and open problems

In this paper, we proved a lower bound for the randomised and address-only quantum query complexity of a cell probe scheme for the static predecessor searching problem. Our lower bound matches the deterministic cell probe upper bound of Beame and Fich. We proved our lower bound by proving a strong round elimination lemma in communication complexity. Our round elimination lemma improves on the round elimination lemma of Miltersen, Nisan, Safra and Wigderson, and is crucial to proving our optimal lower bound for predecessor searching. Our strong round elimination lemma also gives us improved rounds versus communication tradeoffs for the â€˜greater-thanâ€™ problem. We believe that our round elimination lemma is of independent interest and should have other applications. In fact recently, Chakrabarti and RegevÂ [CR03] have proved an optimal lower bound for randomised cell probe schemes for the approximate nearest neighbour searching problem on the Hamming cube {0,1}dsuperscript01ğ‘‘\{0,1\}^{d}{ 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Their proof uses the classical version of our round elimination lemma and combines it with a message switching argument, drawing on the message compression ideas of Jain, Radhakrishnan and SenÂ [JRS03], for classical communication protocols that further exploits the asymmetry in the message lengths of Alice of Bob.

We believe that our work brings out an interesting fact. Sometimes, in order to prove lower bound results, it helps to work in a more general model of computation. Of course, this makes the task of proving lower bounds harder, but also we now have more tools and techniques at our disposal. This sometimes enables us to attack the problem in a clearer fashion, without letting irrelevant details about the restricted model distract us. In our case, our attempt to prove a lower bound result in the more general address-only quantum cell probe model led us to make better use of powerful tools from information theory, which finally enabled us to prove optimal lower bounds for predecessor in the randomised cell probe model! Also, the information-theoretic approach gives us a simpler and clearer lower bound proof as compared to previous lower bound proofs for predecessor.

The lower bound for predecessor searching for quantum cell probe schemes works only if the query scheme is address-only. If the query scheme is not address-only, the asymmetry in the message lengths of Alice and Bob in the corresponding quantum communication protocol breaks down. For a general quantum query scheme, it is an open problem to prove non-trivial lower bounds for static data structure problems.

The message switching idea of Chakrabarti and RegevÂ [CR03] works for classical communication protocols only. Thus, their lower bound for approximate nearest neighbour searching on the Hamming cube holds for classical cell probe schemes only. Our round elimination lemma alone does not seem to be able to fully exploit the asymmetry in the message lengths of Alice and Bob in a communication protocol for this problem. Proving a non-trivial lower bound for this problem in the address-only quantum cell probe model remains an open problem.

Acknowledgements

We thank Rahul Jain, Hartmut Klauck and Peter Bro Miltersen for helpful discussions and feedback, and Amit Chakrabarti for sending us a copy of [CR03]. We also thank Ashwin Nayak for helpful discussions and for pointing out the reference [Man01], and Jaikumar Radhakrishnan for reading an early draft of [SV01] and for enlightening discussions.
