Appendix A The average encoding theorem

A.1 Classical

In this subsection, we give a self-contained classical proof, without using quantum information theory, of FactÂ 5. We first recall the definition of a classical information-theoretic quantity called relative entropy, also known as Kullback-Leibler divergence.

Definition 10 (Relative entropy)

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q be probability distributions on the same sample space Î©normal-Î©\Omegaroman_Î©. The relative entropy between Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is defined as

Sâ¢(Pâˆ¥Q)=Î”âˆ‘xâˆˆÎ©Pâ¢(x)â¢logâ¡(Pâ¢(x)Qâ¢(x)).superscriptÎ”ğ‘†conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„subscriptğ‘¥Î©ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥S(P\|Q)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{x\in\Omega}P(x)\log\left(\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\right).italic_S ( italic_P âˆ¥ italic_Q ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_x ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_P ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Q ( italic_x ) end_ARG ) .

We now require a non-trivial fact from classical information theory, which upper bounds the total variation distance of a pair of probability distributions in terms of their relative entropy. A proof of the fact can be found in [CT91, LemmaÂ 12.6.1].

Fact 10

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q be probability distributions on the same finite sample space Î©normal-Î©\Omegaroman_Î©. Then,

â€–Pâˆ’Qâ€–1â‰¤(2â¢lnâ¡2)â¢Sâ¢(Pâˆ¥Q).subscriptnormğ‘ƒğ‘„122ğ‘†conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„\|P-Q\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{(2\ln 2)S(P\|Q)}.âˆ¥ italic_P - italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_S ( italic_P âˆ¥ italic_Q ) end_ARG .

We can now prove FactÂ 5.


FactÂ 5 (Average encoding theorem, classical version) Let X,Mğ‘‹ğ‘€X,Mitalic_X , italic_M be correlated random variables. Let pxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥p_{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the (marginal) probability that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x, and Î xsuperscriptnormal-Î ğ‘¥\Pi^{x}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the conditional distribution of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M given that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let Î normal-Î \Piroman_Î  denote the (marginal) probability distribution of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M i.e. Î =âˆ‘xpxâ¢Î xnormal-Î subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptnormal-Î ğ‘¥\Pi=\sum_{x}p_{x}\Pi^{x}roman_Î  = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then,

âˆ‘xpxâ¢â€–Î xâˆ’Î â€–1â‰¤(2ln2)I(X:M).\sum_{x}p_{x}\|\Pi^{x}-\Pi\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{(2\ln 2)I(X:M)}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Î  âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG ( 2 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) end_ARG .

Proof: Let ğ’³ğ’³{\cal X}caligraphic_X, â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M be the finite ranges of random variables Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M respectively. We define two probability distributions Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q on ğ’³Ã—â„³ğ’³â„³{\cal X}\times{\cal M}caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_M. In distribution Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, the probability of (x,m)âˆˆğ’³Ã—â„³ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ’³â„³(x,m)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal M}( italic_x , italic_m ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_M is pxâ‹…Ï€mxâ‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥p_{x}\cdot\pi_{m}^{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Ï€mxsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥\pi_{m}^{x}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the conditional probability that M=mğ‘€ğ‘šM=mitalic_M = italic_m given that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. In distribution Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, the probability of (x,m)âˆˆğ’³Ã—â„³ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ’³â„³(x,m)\in{\cal X}\times{\cal M}( italic_x , italic_m ) âˆˆ caligraphic_X Ã— caligraphic_M is pxâ‹…Ï€mâ‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‹ğ‘šp_{x}\cdot\pi_{m}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Ï€msubscriptğœ‹ğ‘š\pi_{m}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the (marginal) probability that M=mğ‘€ğ‘šM=mitalic_M = italic_m i.e. Ï€m=âˆ‘xpxâ¢Ï€mxsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘šğ‘¥\pi_{m}=\sum_{x}p_{x}\pi_{m}^{x}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

It is easy to check that S(Pâˆ¥Q)=I(X:M)S(P\|Q)=I(X:M)italic_S ( italic_P âˆ¥ italic_Q ) = italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) and â€–Pâˆ’Qâ€–1=âˆ‘xpxâ¢â€–Î xâˆ’Î â€–1subscriptnormğ‘ƒğ‘„1subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptnormsubscriptÎ ğ‘¥Î 1\|P-Q\|_{1}=\sum_{x}p_{x}\|\Pi_{x}-\Pi\|_{1}âˆ¥ italic_P - italic_Q âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î  âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The result now follows by applying FactÂ 10 to Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. Â 

A.2 Quantum

In this subsection, we give a proof of FactÂ 9. We first recall some basic definitions and facts from quantum information theory. Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ be density matrices in the same finite dimensional Hilbert space â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. The fidelity (also called Uhlmannâ€™s transition probability or the Bhattacharya coefficient) of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ is defined as Bâ¢(Ï,Ïƒ)=Î”â€–Ïâ¢Ïƒâ€–1superscriptÎ”ğµğœŒğœsubscriptnormğœŒğœ1B(\rho,\sigma)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\|\sqrt{\rho}\sqrt{\sigma}\|_{1}italic_B ( italic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ¥ square-root start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The von Neumann relative entropy between ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ is defined as Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)=Î”TrÂ â¢(Ïâ¢(logâ¡Ïâˆ’logâ¡Ïƒ))superscriptÎ”ğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœTrÂ ğœŒğœŒğœS(\rho\|\sigma)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\mbox{{\rm Tr} }(\rho(\log\rho-\log\sigma))italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP Tr ( italic_Ï ( roman_log italic_Ï - roman_log italic_Ïƒ ) ).

JozsaÂ [Joz94] gave an elementary proof for finite dimensional Hilbert spaces of the following basic and remarkable property about fidelity.

Fact 11

Let Ï,ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho,\sigmaitalic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ be density matrices in the same Hilbert space â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. Let ğ’¦ğ’¦{\cal K}caligraphic_K be a disjoint Hilbert space such that dim(ğ’¦)â‰¥dim(â„‹)dimensionğ’¦dimensionâ„‹\dim({\cal K})\geq\dim({\cal H})roman_dim ( caligraphic_K ) â‰¥ roman_dim ( caligraphic_H ). Then for any purification |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle| italic_Ïˆ âŸ© of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K, there exists a purification |Ï•âŸ©ketitalic-Ï•|\phi\rangle| italic_Ï• âŸ© of Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K such that Bâ¢(Ï,Ïƒ)=|âŸ¨Ïˆ|Ï•âŸ©|ğµğœŒğœinner-productğœ“italic-Ï•B(\rho,\sigma)=|\langle\psi|\phi\rangle|italic_B ( italic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ ) = | âŸ¨ italic_Ïˆ | italic_Ï• âŸ© |.

For two probability distributions P,Qğ‘ƒğ‘„P,Qitalic_P , italic_Q on the same sample space Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î©, their fidelity is defined as Bâ¢(P,Q)=Î”âˆ‘xâˆˆÎ©Pâ¢(x)â¢Qâ¢(x)superscriptÎ”ğµğ‘ƒğ‘„subscriptğ‘¥Î©ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥B(P,Q)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}\sum_{x\in\Omega}\sqrt{P(x)Q(x)}italic_B ( italic_P , italic_Q ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_P ( italic_x ) italic_Q ( italic_x ) end_ARG. We will need the following result about fidelity proved by Fuchs and CavesÂ [FC95].

Fact 12

Let Ï,ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho,\sigmaitalic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ be density matrices in the same Hilbert space â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. Then Bâ¢(Ï,Ïƒ)=infâ„³Bâ¢(â„³â¢Ï,â„³â¢Ïƒ)ğµğœŒğœsubscriptinfimumâ„³ğµâ„³ğœŒâ„³ğœ\displaystyle B(\rho,\sigma)=\inf_{{\cal M}}B({\cal M}\rho,{\cal M}\sigma)italic_B ( italic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ ) = roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ( caligraphic_M italic_Ï , caligraphic_M italic_Ïƒ ), where â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M ranges over POVMâ€™s on â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. In fact, the infimum above can be attained by a complete von Neumann measurement on â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H.

The following fundamental fact (see e.gÂ [NC00]) states that the relative entropy can only decrease on performing a measurement.

Fact 13 (Monotonicity of relative entropy)

Let Ï,ÏƒğœŒğœ\rho,\sigmaitalic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ be density matrices in the same finite dimensional Hilbert space â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. Let â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M be a POVM on â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H. Then, Sâ¢(â„³â¢Ïâˆ¥â„³â¢Ïƒ)â‰¤Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)ğ‘†conditionalâ„³ğœŒâ„³ğœğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœS({\cal M}\rho\|{\cal M}\sigma)\leq S(\rho\|\sigma)italic_S ( caligraphic_M italic_Ï âˆ¥ caligraphic_M italic_Ïƒ ) â‰¤ italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ).

We require the following explicit expression for the trace distance of two pure states (see e.g.Â [NC00]).

Fact 14

For pure states |ÏˆâŸ©ketğœ“|\psi\rangle| italic_Ïˆ âŸ© and |Ï•âŸ©ketitalic-Ï•|\phi\rangle| italic_Ï• âŸ© in the same Hilbert space, â€–|ÏˆâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ïˆ|âˆ’|Ï•âŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ï•|â€–1=2â¢1âˆ’|âŸ¨Ïˆ|Ï•âŸ©|2subscriptnormketğœ“brağœ“ketitalic-Ï•braitalic-Ï•121superscriptinner-productğœ“italic-Ï•2\||\psi\rangle\langle\psi|-|\phi\rangle\langle\phi|\|_{1}=2\sqrt{1-|\langle\psi|\phi\rangle|^{2}}âˆ¥ | italic_Ïˆ âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ïˆ | - | italic_Ï• âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ï• | âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 square-root start_ARG 1 - | âŸ¨ italic_Ïˆ | italic_Ï• âŸ© | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

The following information-theoretic fact follows easily from the definitions.

Fact 15

Let X,Mğ‘‹ğ‘€X,Mitalic_X , italic_M be quantum systems with some joint density matrix, where Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is a classical random variable. Let pxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥p_{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the (marginal) probability that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x and ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the conditional density matrix of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M given that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï denote the reduced density matrix of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M. Note that Ï=âˆ‘xpxâ¢ÏxğœŒsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho=\sum_{x}p_{x}\rho^{x}italic_Ï = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, I(X:M)=âˆ‘xpxS(Ïxâˆ¥Ï)I(X:M)=\sum_{x}p_{x}S(\rho^{x}\|\rho)italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï ).

We now recall the following direct connection between relative entropy and fidelity observed in the classical setting by [DHR78], and in the quantum setting by Klauck (private communication).

Fact 16

Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ be two density matrices in the same Hilbert space. Then,

1âˆ’Bâ¢(Ï,Ïƒ)â‰¤(lnâ¡2)â¢Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)2.1ğµğœŒğœ2ğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœ21-B(\rho,\sigma)\leq\frac{(\ln 2)S(\rho\|\sigma)}{2}.1 - italic_B ( italic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG ( roman_ln 2 ) italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

Proof: Let â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M be the complete von Neumann measurement that achieves the infimum in FactÂ 12. Let Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© denote the set of possible (classical) outcomes of â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M. Define probability distributions P=Î”â„³â¢ÏsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒâ„³ğœŒP\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}{\cal M}\rhoitalic_P start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP caligraphic_M italic_Ï and Q=Î”â„³â¢ÏƒsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘„â„³ğœQ\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\Delta}}{{=}}{\cal M}\sigmaitalic_Q start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG end_RELOP caligraphic_M italic_Ïƒ. From FactÂ 13 and concavity of the log\logroman_log function it follows that

âˆ’Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)2â‰¤âˆ’Sâ¢(Pâˆ¥Q)2=âˆ‘xâˆˆÎ©Pâ¢(x)â¢logâ¡Qâ¢(x)Pâ¢(x)â‰¤logâ¢âˆ‘xâˆˆÎ©Qâ¢(x)â¢Pâ¢(x)=logâ¡Bâ¢(P,Q)=logâ¡Bâ¢(Ï,Ïƒ).ğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœ2ğ‘†conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„2subscriptğ‘¥Î©ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘¥absentsubscriptğ‘¥Î©ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğµğ‘ƒğ‘„ğµğœŒğœ\begin{array}[]{c}\displaystyle-\frac{S(\rho\|\sigma)}{2}\leq-\frac{S(P\|Q)}{2}=\sum_{x\in\Omega}P(x)\log\sqrt{\frac{Q(x)}{P(x)}}\\ \displaystyle\leq\log\sum_{x\in\Omega}\sqrt{Q(x)P(x)}=\log B(P,Q)=\log B(\rho,\sigma).\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL - divide start_ARG italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‰¤ - divide start_ARG italic_S ( italic_P âˆ¥ italic_Q ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_x ) roman_log square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Q ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P ( italic_x ) end_ARG end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‰¤ roman_log âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_Q ( italic_x ) italic_P ( italic_x ) end_ARG = roman_log italic_B ( italic_P , italic_Q ) = roman_log italic_B ( italic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ ) . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

Thus, Bâ¢(Ï,Ïƒ)â‰¥2âˆ’Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)/2=expâ¡(âˆ’(lnâ¡2)â¢Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)/2)â‰¥1âˆ’((lnâ¡2)â¢Sâ¢(Ïâˆ¥Ïƒ)/2)ğµğœŒğœsuperscript2ğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœ22ğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœ212ğ‘†conditionalğœŒğœ2B(\rho,\sigma)\geq 2^{-S(\rho\|\sigma)/2}=\exp(-(\ln 2)S(\rho\|\sigma)/2)\geq 1-((\ln 2)S(\rho\|\sigma)/2)italic_B ( italic_Ï , italic_Ïƒ ) â‰¥ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ) / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - ( roman_ln 2 ) italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ) / 2 ) â‰¥ 1 - ( ( roman_ln 2 ) italic_S ( italic_Ï âˆ¥ italic_Ïƒ ) / 2 ). Â 

We can now prove FactÂ 9.


FactÂ 9 (Average encoding theorem, quantum version) Let X,Mğ‘‹ğ‘€X,Mitalic_X , italic_M be quantum systems with some joint density matrix. Let Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X be a classical random variable and pxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥p_{x}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the (marginal) probability that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let â„‹â„‹{\cal H}caligraphic_H denote the Hilbert space of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M and ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the conditional density matrix of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M given that X=xğ‘‹ğ‘¥X=xitalic_X = italic_x. Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï denote the reduced density matrix of Mğ‘€Mitalic_M. Note that Ï=âˆ‘xpxâ¢ÏxğœŒsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho=\sum_{x}p_{x}\rho^{x}italic_Ï = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let ğ’¦ğ’¦{\cal K}caligraphic_K denote a disjoint Hilbert space such that dim(ğ’¦)â‰¥dim(â„‹)dimensionğ’¦dimensionâ„‹\dim({\cal K})\geq\dim({\cal H})roman_dim ( caligraphic_K ) â‰¥ roman_dim ( caligraphic_H ). Let |ÏˆxâŸ©ketsuperscriptğœ“ğ‘¥|\psi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© be purifications of ÏxsuperscriptğœŒğ‘¥\rho^{x}italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K. Then there exist purifications |Ï•xâŸ©ketsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥|\phi^{x}\rangle| italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï in â„‹âŠ—ğ’¦tensor-productâ„‹ğ’¦{\cal H}\otimes{\cal K}caligraphic_H âŠ— caligraphic_K such that

âˆ‘xpxâ¢â€–|ÏˆxâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ïˆx|âˆ’|Ï•xâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ï•x|â€–1â‰¤(4ln2)I(X:M).\sum_{x}p_{x}\||\psi^{x}\rangle\langle\psi^{x}|-|\phi^{x}\rangle\langle\phi^{x}|\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{(4\ln 2)I(X:M)}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ | italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | - | italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ¨ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ square-root start_ARG ( 4 roman_ln 2 ) italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) end_ARG .

Proof: Using the concavity of the square root function, FactsÂ 15, 11, 14, 16, and the fact that fidelity is always at most 1111, we get

I(X:M)=âˆ‘xpxâ¢Sâ¢(Ïxâˆ¥Ï)â‰¥âˆ‘xpxâ¢Sâ¢(Ïxâˆ¥Ï)â‰¥âˆ‘xpxâ¢2â¢(1âˆ’Bâ¢(Ïx,Ï))lnâ¡2â‰¥âˆ‘xpxâ¢1âˆ’(Bâ¢(Ïx,Ï))2lnâ¡2=âˆ‘xpxâ¢1âˆ’|âŸ¨Ïˆx|Ï•xâŸ©|2lnâ¡2=âˆ‘xpxâ¢â€–|ÏˆxâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ïˆx|âˆ’|Ï•xâŸ©â¢âŸ¨Ï•x|â€–14â¢lnâ¡2.\begin{array}[]{c}\displaystyle\sqrt{I(X:M)}=\sqrt{\sum_{x}p_{x}S(\rho^{x}\|\rho)}\geq\sum_{x}p_{x}\sqrt{S(\rho^{x}\|\rho)}\geq\sum_{x}p_{x}\sqrt{\frac{2(1-B(\rho^{x},\rho))}{\ln 2}}\\ \displaystyle\geq\sum_{x}p_{x}\sqrt{\frac{1-(B(\rho^{x},\rho))^{2}}{\ln 2}}=\sum_{x}p_{x}\sqrt{\frac{1-|\langle\psi^{x}|\phi^{x}\rangle|^{2}}{\ln 2}}=\sum_{x}p_{x}\frac{\||\psi^{x}\rangle\langle\psi^{x}|-|\phi^{x}\rangle\langle\phi^{x}|\|_{1}}{\sqrt{4\ln 2}}.\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL square-root start_ARG italic_I ( italic_X : italic_M ) end_ARG = square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï ) end_ARG â‰¥ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_S ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï ) end_ARG â‰¥ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( 1 -
